38824331.review:
Aviary Attorney is an indie masterpiece!
It excels at different types of artistical expression, the artstyle is charming and heavily inspired in those old illustrations, specifically J. J. Grandville's illustrations that portrayed animals in human form; The Soundtrack contains the compositions of the Great musician Camille Saint-saens that fits perfectly in the game; And the story is very well written, looking a lot like old detective and mistery novels, but with a sense of humor.

You play the role of a lawyer (no, not the real life greedy monster, but the fictional good citizen who cares deeply about justice) that wanders around the city of Paris looking for clues and evidences that would help your case.
In terms of gameplay, it is a visual novel, so gameplay is not really the focus, but it doesnt disappoint, you have the responsability of carrying the story, you have to make decisions and drive the plot, your choices matter, but due to the obvious limitations of a 2D game featuring still images as characters, it is no ''Life is Strange''. 
Aside from making choices you can also, search an area for evidence, defend your client in several trials, interview witness and citizens around the town, carefully manage your days and where to go on the map (you only have one place per day to investigate in a very short period of time till the next trial) and even gamble!

But I need to point out that the game is actually pretty easy, it only takes simple deduction and a minimal level of intelligence to figure things out, the evidences are pretty easy to find, the people basically vomit clues on you all the time, but of course, if you dont make the right decision you might miss things. But all that is not really important, since, as I said, its a visual novel, the story needs to unfold in front of us. its just a bit distracting that things happen too conveniently, theres ALWAYS evidence, ALWAYS traces of the guilty man, ALWAYS witnesses that you happen to stumble into, things that dont really happen in real life, and if it wasnt a game, it would be pretty unbelievable as a story too.

For an indie project that was kickstarted, the game has a lot of quality, specially since it was made by a small group of people, Ive seen lots of indie productions that lack this kind of quality, Even if they borrowed most of the characters, scenery and music, the animation is good too, the way the camera moves, how characters interact and all that. But, if Im going to nitpick... When the designs are not borrowed from J.J. Grandville's works... it kinda shows... you can spot which characters were created for the game and which ones were Grandville's, and even if you couldn't spot it, there's a specific part of the game that broke the esperience a little bit for me, that is when they have a trial underground, in a place full of bones and skulls, the scenery there reveals a very amateur work, an artstyle that doesnt belong on such a beautiful game, again, im nitpicking, but that bothered me a little and it would be much better if the team had an extra effort to make that part of the game a little bit prettier.

Another nitpick is the fact that the game doesnt feature acchivements and doesnt let you screenshot in-game (maybe thats only a problem for me), those small features are part of what makes it a special experience to play this game on STEAM, instead of you know... downloading it illegally (which is a huge dick move to an indie game).

Those are the only ''complaints'' I can really make about the game, the story is a very pleasant experience and I can say that I was completely hooked by it, thats the sign of a good mistery, you cant stop until you've discovered it. And of course, by making different choices you unlock different endings too, which is great because there's a lot of replay value, you cant just uncover every part of the game and its misteries in a single playthrough. The characters are very likeable and well written, and the story brings intriguing themes about the concept of justice and revolution.
Its a very nice and well put together game that you should own right now.

38799571.review:
I want to wholeheartedly recomend this game, but I can't. 
I can however give a strong qualified recommendation.
In some ways, Aviary Attorney feels like a fan game of the Ace Attorney series, but I don't mean that in a pejorative way. It's  just clear that it's heavily inspired Ace Attorney, and it is loving take on similar narrative/gameplay themes and story beats.  That being said, it's got a lot of it's own unique ideas both in terms of its setting and it's gameplay that prevent it from feeling derivative.  However, there are a few problems that prevent it from reaching excellence.

First of all, the game is somewhat buggy; the game regularly crashed either on launch or when attempting to enter full screen mode.  Additionally, it's lacking some features that are critical  for game which is predominantly text, such as a text log and an option to skip previously read text.  The game contains a lot of alternate dialog and several different endings, but the inability to quickly skip previously read text makes accessing this content more of a chore than it needs to be.
Additionally the game suffers from pacing problems.  Ironically, it has the opposite pacing problem that the Ace Attorney series has.  Often Ace Attorney games feel needlessly long and dragged out, whereas Aviary Attorney goes by far too quickly.  Otherwise satisfying character growth arcs feel rushed, reveals of dramatic twists come too suddenly and feel un-earned and the excellent setting isn't adequately explored.  This effects the gameplay as well, as the cross examinations are extremely simple and underwhelming. 
Regardless  for a sale price of under 5 dollars, Aviary Attorney is an enjoyable, if brief experience that truly deserves a sequel which is expanded in scope.

38127462.review:
Birds have a long history in gaming, dating back to the mascot wars of the 90s. Games like Sonic the Hedgehog, Spyro the Dragon, and Crash Bandicoot all brought birds to the forefront of gaming entertainment with their colorful bird protagonists, hinting at a bright future for avian kind. But as console generations came and went, the medium's focus shifted, and birds were all but lost in the gaming spectrum. Thankfully, all is not lost, and thanks to sleeper hits like Hatoful Boyfriend and Penguins Arena and the popular Tropes vs. Birds video series by Tweeta Parakeetian, birds are back, and better than ever - which brings us to the latest in bird entertainment, Aviary Attorney.

Avian Attorney is, as it says in the title, a game about birds practicing in the school of law - unlike its bird of a feather, Hatoful Boyfriend (which held its surprise so close to its plumage that even today most people still think it's a joke game about dating birds), this time it's just you, the birds, and the mysteries within. While it's not necessarily an original idea, predated by famous bird lawyer series Harvey Birdman: Attorney at Law more than a decade ago, it provides a fresh perspective through its unique presentation, in both its art style and music.

In terms of gameplay, Aviary Attorney will probably come as second nature to anyone familiar with the similarly named Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney series (which, despite its misleading title, is not about mystical birds). It's a visual novel with mystery elements, in which you travel between various locations gathering evidence leading up to a court trial. Unlike Phoenix Wright, however, travelling between most locations takes a day of your time, and you only have a certain amount of time before each court session begins, making you think more about where you need to go. There are four cases, with minor choices throughout the cases that lend to replayability (and frequently leave you wondering whether or not you've made a mistake), and the fourth case has 3 varients which are vary significantly both in story and length, and altogether the game lasted me around 7 hours. There are occasional bugs here and there, but the developer seems to be working hard to iron out the problems and in the time I've been playing it there have already been two small patches for it. If you're a fan of mystery games, particularly of the Ace Attorney variety, this is a pretty easy purchase overall. It has enough original elements to keep veterans of the genre on their talons, while providing more of the mysteries that they love.

37976563.review:
[SPOILER FREE]

As you might've read in the description, this game is about bird attorneys, set in the nineteenth-century France, where each character is a different animal. You fill the role of a defense attorney, Jayjay Falcon, and It plays much like a visual novel. The game is divided into the investigation bits, where you visit different places with your lackey Sparrowson, and pick up pieces of evidence, and the trial bits, where you use everything you collected to defend your client from the prosecution.

PROS
++The humor. I do understand that humor is subjective, but I must say the silliness of the jokes and puns hit just the right spot with me. While the game sports a 'revolution' sort of theme, it doesn't take itself that seriously for the most part.

+The character design is amazing. I understand the art was taken from public domain, and it fit really well with the theme of the game.

+While I think the game lacked more... 'climaxy' music, I thought it also fit just fine with the scenario and the thematic, overall.

CONS
-Story is a bit too short. I pretty much finished the 4 cases in 6 hours (averaging 90 minutes per case), and I could see in the reviews that some people took even less time to finish the game.

-Lack of different poses. The characters use the same pose most of the time, so the game feels a bit... static. The characters only show different emotions through text, pretty much.

-The game also lacks a quicksave feature. So you pretty much have to rely on the daily autosaves, and as such, you can't do things like stop the game mid-trial and pick it up later. The fact that the cases are short makes it so that this isn't much of a problem though, but it'd be a welcome feature nonetheless.

NEUTRAL POINTS
The story. It's not bad, but it's not particularly great either. I thought it was interesting, and I was entertained throughout the game, so I think it does the job fine, though.

The difficulty of the cases. They're pretty easy for the most part. None of them require that much out of the player to deduce what transpired (save for a particular plot twist), and I didn't have any trouble on figuring out when to present what evidence. It's still fun enough, though.

COMMENT
One thing I think I should point out: you CAN lose trials and the game WILL continue. As such, when you're doing the investigation bits, don't hesitate to use your player powers to reload the game if you feel you did things in the wrong order, because you can miss pieces of important evidence. Or if you're fine with that, just roll with it and do your best, and replay the game later if you want to get a different ending or different outcomes for the trials.

CONCLUSION
While it has its problems, I do recommend this game, especially if you've played the Ace Attorney series or you're a fan of courtroom drama (or comedy). The base price is a bit steep though, so pick it up when it's 50%~75% off.

A very good but unpolished game. We'll start with the flaws. The biggest flaw is the lack of skip option, so if you have to replay, you must click through ALL the dialogue, which is a huge hassle since there are many opportunities for mistakes. Another flaw is the lack of direction the game provides. This one is arguable though, since it does provide challenge and goes along with the theme of living with one's choices and mistakes.

However, despite these shortcomings, I found this game to be a very unique experience in many ways. Mostly in that the choices are not black and white and whatever mistakes you do make, the show must go on, allowing you to continue the story but still reminding you of your failures. 

I found the setting and story grade A. The developers did a great job on their research, and many of the historical references flew over my head. I really enjoyed the grimness and gray morality of the story despite its silly exterior and humor present. In fact, I think they blended the humor and heaviness of the story very well. 

Expect puns. Many puns.

37716496.review:
When I first got this game, I was quite happy with it. The nods to Ace Attorney were fun and amusing, especially to someone like me who really likes the series, and it played the mood very well. And then I won the first trial, and it made me lose my shit, it was amazing. THe second act was interesting and fun, and the third was nail-biting and tense. However...
The fourth act is where this game lost me. From here, if you want to avoid spoilers, stop reading, and know that despite not liking the fourth act, it doesn't break the game for me and I still reccomend it. This next bit is primarily for the developers.

4a is... Well, 4a feels more like a farce than anything else, especially since the opportunity is given to speak up and you're even asked if you're sure if you don't want to speak. From a gameplay standpoint, the only reason you would chose this option is out of pure curiosity or if you truly, TRULY hate the character that's about to die. There's no logical and barely any emotional reason to chose this option, which makes the fact that it gives you an entirely seperate ending sequence all the more frustrating, and it makes Falcon look like a fucking idiot for throwing a fit and doing what he does afterwards. He blames the resistance, but he gives up a very clear and consice opporunity to step in and at least TRY to do something about it. 
If you made this ending result from getting lost in the catacombs and being too late, it would read so much better, especially since the guard makes a remark about you not having a torch, it leads the player to believe that getting lost is possible. As it is, you actually cannot get lost in the catacombs, I actually tried. If you made the ending result from getting lost and arriving too late rather than Falcon actively chosing not to speak up, it would make more sense that he doesn't place blame on himself and instead on Beaumont, viewing it as he did the best he could. From there, giving up being a lawyer and leaving it to Sparrowson makes sense from an emotional and character standpoint. 
Sparrowson... doesn't make for a strong player character. He was built to be a companion/comic relief and it shows. That said, I don't think the narritive suffers TOO much for it. The investigating is simple but relatively solid, the trial is at least somewhat interesting, and Falcon's actions and motives are engaging. The conversations with Beaumort are decent as well. That said, there really isn't an end to this... ending. It just stops. The fire happens, we're told the revolution happens, and that's it. You can chose whether or not to turn Falcon in, but it doesn't change much either way.

Ending 4b, on the other hand, is atrocious. For successfully saving Cocorico, you get an ending that railroads you and is boring. The only real choice you have is in what order to go places, and the trial is a joke at best, seeing as it doesn't matter what you do or what choices you make, the King still looks shitty. The Viridian Killer is revealed for seemingly no reason, the bombings happen, the revolution just happens, and the King is fooled and probably killed, who knows, I didn't pay attention. There's no gameplay, no real climax, everything just kind of happens and you sit back and watch. At best, it's stupid and boring, at worst, it's arbitrary and makes you feel cheated. This is a massive missed opportunity to actually show the king in a grey light instead of a bad one, or to get Falcon in trouble with the Revolution for daring to defend the king and twist the truth to make him look better. As it is, this ending holds no appeal, no weight, nothing but a boring ending painted as happily ever after, and even then, it's just stupid. I don't have anything against happy endings, but it doesn't fit with the rest of the game and all and getting this ending for doing everything right made me feel like I'd been cheated.
I think the major issue, though, is the fact that in a game that takes the Black/White morality you expect and turns it on its head to paint the world in wonderful, engaging shades of gray (funny, considering the visuals themselves are in black and white), the king and the trial are painted so starkly black and white that it yanks you out of the experieince. As I said, nothing you do makes any difference, and you might as well have not collected any evidence at all. Not a single person you talk to has a nice word to say about the king and the king himself shows no sign of actually having any good in him either. It's a large, black stain on an otherwise beautifuly gray game.

As for 4c... It starts off relatively strong, especially compared to the other two endings. You fail the trial and Cocorico is killed. You're given a choice to join or die, and joining does seem like a decent option, at least to help survive. If you've been paying attention at all, you'll know exactly what to ask Fontaine about to distract him so Sparrowson can escape. Then you go around with Beaumort and see things from her point of view, for the most part. It doesn't quell your anger about, or justify her killing, Cocorico, but it shows the rebels in a more sympathetic light and shows they really are trying to make things better. I think it does bring a bit more of the problem with black/white morality in a world that's painted gray, but it's not as bad as with the king, because it's shown that while the Rebellion have good intentions, all of them are relatively grey in morality, such as Fontaine and Pierro having the argument about what they owe each other and Beaumort herself letting her emotions overcome her want for the Revolution to be nonviolent when it comes to her father's death and Cocorico.
It also feels like you could be influencing her, especially with the discussions about barricades and the police, and gives you the hope that even if you can't stop the revolution, you could at least coax it to be less violent. And you do indeed. Of course, the wolves have to go fuck it up, which is frustrating, but not in a bad storytelling way, more in a "fuck you villian" way. You're not alone in thinking the police had nothing to do with it, as another of the Rebellion thinks so as well, which is a great move, as it keeps the narritive from spiraling into total despair and gives you an ally, helping the drive to fight for the truth and giving the notion you will be able to potentially have a trial and find the truth. And when you do, things go to shit because of the Friar. That said, there are only two issues I have with this one.
One, it's too easy. You have one piece of evidence literally handed to you, and the fact that Volerti doesn't have a left hand could have been left to the player to point out from if they've been paying attention, and overall, it's just kind of blowing over. That said, it's better than 4b, since you actually can fail, and it doesn't feel like you're being railroaded, simply that you're pointing out the obvious in some places.
Second, what happens after the fighting starts is sort of... Strange. I don't see the narritive point of having the fates of Beaumort and Falcon be ambiguous/having them disappear, especially since the Second Republic won. Who is their new leader? What happened to the others? It leaves questions, but those questions feel like the game is simply waving its hands in front of the player and shouting "OOOOOH ISN'T THIS SO MYSTERIOUS????" It's not awful, just strange.
Overall, 4c is the best written of the three endings, and the only one that was actually fun to play, which is disapointing seeing as it's the ending that results from losing the trial in Act 3.

When all is said and done, though, I really enjoyed this game. For the first attempt from this game dev, it was astoundingly solid overall, and if a second game came out, I would likely buy it. I hope this review can help the devs write better endings for their games like this in the future, and I'd love to see more from them.

'Aviary Attorney' is een visuele novelle, geïnspireerd door de 'Ace Attorney'-serie. Je neemt in deze game de rol op je van Jayjay Falcon, een gevleugelde advocaat. Ik zal in deze korte recensie vooral de game vergelijken met Ace Attorney.

- De visuele stijl is monochroom en geïnspireerd door oude karikaturen. Het is visueel indrukwekkend, maar niet zo expressief als de animatie, kleur en ontwerpen van Ace Attorney personages.

- De gameplay bestaat vooral uit klikken op objecten in de omgeving, dialoogkeuzes maken en (in de rechtzaken) bewijzen uit je inventaris presenteren. De structuur is bijna identiek aan Ace Attorney, maar het kost een in-game dag om een lokatie te bezoeken, dus je kunt de rechtzaak ingaan zonder dat je alle bewijzen hebt gevonden.

- In Ace Attorney begint het hoofdstuk opnieuw als je een zaak verliest. In Aviary Attorney gaat het verhaal door, ongeacht of je wint of verliest. Dit geeft het verhaal de ruimte om te veranderen op basis van je keuzes, en het laatste hoofdstuk kan zich op drie totaal unieke manieren vertakken afhangende van je keuzes.

- Het overkoepelende verhaal is interessant en berust op echte gebeurtenissen in de Franse geschiedenis.

Aan te raden voor fans van de Ace Attorney serie en andere mensen die op zoek zijn naar moordmysteries.

The question has to be asked, How much does this game cost? 15 dollars? For 5.4 Hrs? But it must be said that I played every English Ace Attorney game. So the game might not have been able to trick my already programed brain.

Speaking about Ace Attorney, how much does this game steal from that? Well the very basics but it also does a few things from the Ace Attorney Alpha. The Alpha of the famous Game Boy Advance game turned Game Boy DS was that the entire court case would be performed live. Every choice you made and every moment you saw, if done incorrectly could lead to your loss.

This is a game where you can lose. Not from life lost or quick bad end choice but from other reasons.

Now with that spoler out of the way....

Aviary Attorney does not have much animashion. Again it uses the basic drawings of Mr  J. J. Grandville, The mouth movement of characters are well enough. But outside of jumping about and false turning there is not much animashion around. Of course the game will do it's best with this limit and some of the jokes are funny. The music is good enough and sets a a basic tone. The backgrounds are again of Mr. J J so they are very nice to look at. And the options of getting around in the game are very nicely done. It makes sure you will have track of what you need and who every character is.

Overall I will have to say that the story is very nice for an Ace Attorney player. It will have some major diffrences and will feel fresh. To people that have never played that game this should be enough of a experince into the limited "lawyer logic" games out there. Speaking of that I would look into a free Konergate game called Socrates Jones: Pro Philosopher. Get past the very first character and ask you self. "Was this fun?" "Was this wasteful?" "Do I want to keep going?"

If that game bore you to tears, well then Aviary Attorney would have more plot and a much serious case on its hands. Overall thought if you did enjoy it, your likely to enjoy Aviary Attorney. I mean that. People that enjoy games that you need to read a lot and go with logic will enjoy this. The game is also slightly harder.

But now I'll finish with this. Since 2016 the group behind this game have gone quiet. Apparently some side game or other story was to be released. So...You might want to also look into what Kickstarter project offered and what they delivered.

Thats all. It gets my thumbs up.

35238603.review:
Aviary Attorney is a visual novel that follows the adventures of defense lawyer Jayjay Falcon and his cheeky assistant Sparrowson. The player investigates crime scenes and collects evidence, which eventually must be presented in court.

What makes this game so adorable are its unusual but inspired design choices: The setting - Paris mere days before the revolution of 1848 - makes use of contemporary caricatures by J. J. Grandville. The illustrations are perfectly complemented by the  classic compositions of Camille Saint-Saens' Carnival of the Animals. The dialog is often tongue-in-cheek or just plain silly, the characters likeable.

The game only lasts 6-10 hours. But the plot is smarter than it seems at first, positively sucker-punching the player a few times. It's absolutely possible to miss out on vital pieces of evidence or make the wrong conclusions, and thus losing a case. I liked that a lot!

Si la langue de Shakespeare ne vous fait pas peur, foncez! Par contre, un peu court (6h pour le parcourir une fois)

This game has a poor plot, treacly character development, and very little dramatic tension. [Mild spoilers]

I genuinely laughed at a lot of the comic relief, but that couldn't make up for the click-click nature of the 'investigation' portions of the game. The third case was especially frustrating - I had to redo it several times, not because I couldn't guess the chain of logic, but because I hadn't done things in the correct order. 

The trials were too short, and seemed to have no legal world-rules at all (contrast with Ace Attorney, where the notion of 'guilty until proven innocent' was pretty amusing once you got used to it).

Overall, if you like sleuthing, you'll find the process asks nothing of you mentally, but does require you to get lucky. If you like trials, you'll be frustrated by the bizarre rhetorical and procedural leaps you must make to fit the evidence you have. If you like character development, you'll find that there isn't much - Just a mild surprise about a few of the charaters' pasts at the end, and some friends-after-all feelgoodery. If you like jokes about eating too much, there are some good ones in here.

34315912.review:
NOTE: Playtime is inaccurate, I played for six hours in offline mode.

Aviary Attorney is an animal themed take on Phoenix Wright with a French Revolution era twist.

Pros: 
+Iconic art style is both detailed and full of charm
+Many unique animal characters, each one a clever use of their respective animal
+Revised Phoenix Wright formula that makes investigation sequences, examining rooms, and cross examining more streamlined and less frustrating overall
+A creative storyline with surprisingly deep themes
+Multiple endings
+The game will not hold your hand; you CAN LOSE TRIALS and the game WILL progress. Your client's life is truly in your hands more than ever before.
+The ability to select an investigation day and load it from the start menu cuts makes it easy to backtrack should you fail a trial

Cons:
-Some of the mysteries are too simple, far easier to figure out than the ones in the earlier Phoenix Wright games.
-Relatively short at six hours to get one ending (add another hour or two for the others)

Aviary Attorney, despite being clearly inspired by another game series, is a truly unique gem of a game bursting with charming characters and visuals, not to mention an intriging plot filled with political turmoil. Anyone, Phoenix Wright fan or no, will get a kick out of this game.

34117683.review:
This game was introduced to me as a mix of two things I like: birds, and the Ace Attorney series, so I knew I was probably going to enjoy it going in.

I was actually expecting it to be a little heavier on the Ace Attorney spoofing, but honestly? This game can stand on its own merit. It doesn't hold your hand too much in the first trial, it's not too difficult, and it has a good sense of when to allow you to present the evidence you know you have.

The overarching storyline is interesting in its own right, and is what really helps this game stand alone. I'm not going to spoil anything, but even though I'm not a huge history buff, or France buff, I didn't feel lost or disinterested during the goings-on of the setting.

My only real criticisms are thus: Some points at the very very end felt a bit quickly paced, but at the same time, I feel as if they had to be that way. The path that matters most (in my opinion, at least) is the most satisfying in this manner. Additionally, the same ending music is used for the conclusion of each path, which (again, trying to avoid spoilers) doesn't fit with every progression, and it created a dissonant mood in some circumstances.

Otherwise, I just find myself wishing there were more to play.  Unique art style, a good balance of serious moments and humorous ones, and a story outside "some courtroom cases in France," this game's definitely worth your time.

Illustrazioni meravigliose, musiche e soundtrack in generale di ottima fattura, i protagonisti principali sono ben strutturati nonostante la disarmante brevità del titolo.
Poteva e doveva essere aumentata non solo la quantità di casi ma soprattutto la complessità degli stessi; anche se non necessariamente ai livelli estremi di un Ace Attorney, il titolo avrebbe beneficiato della maggiore profondità dei casi sotto molteplici aspetti: migliore caratterizzazione dei personaggi, incremento della durata del titolo, maggiore senso di soddisfazione e non ultimo, situazioni più variegate.
Un apprezzamento particolare va comunque espresso per il design. la qualità delle illustrazioni e le interazioni fra personaggi: nessun è identico agli altri, il che offre una varietà vitale alle loro interazioni, in particolare vedere il responsabile di una biblioteca ottocentesca essere un asino, e questi rimproverare i protagonisti per la loro inferiorità intellettuale è esilarante.
Buon gioco, ma da acquistare ad un prezzo ragionevole.

33832749.review:
Charming and picturesque, [h1]Aviary Attorney[/h1] is a very well written text adventure game following the style of the 'Ace Attorney' games.

I'm gonna start by saying that the illustrations the game has are absolutely fantastic. There's an wonderful amount of detail and love made in each and every one of them and they provide a great way to convey the theme of 19th century France in which the story takes place. You might be thinking that lack of graphics would make the game feel dull and empty,but in all honestly the great works of French caricaturist J. J. Grandville, while seeming like a relic of bygone era when the artists had very few options and mediums to express their craft, manage to build a perfectly fitting atmosphere for the player to experience the story. The background illustrations are an accurate historic depiction of 19th century Paris based on public domain lithographs. It's really some amazing work that the developers have put into creating this gem of a game and it shows from the very first moments.

Music and soundtrack is by legendary romantic-era composer Camille Saint-Saëns and it creates a suitable audio experience that ties greatly with the game. Many of the classical compositions you will listen during your playthrough are familiar via other works of art but they never feel like out of place for the game.

The characters despite not uttering a single line of audio dialogue, excel by the phenomenal writing of the game. They are very colorful and have their own quirks which will you pleasantly discover during the playthrough. They can be funny, ruthless, conniving, innocent or just pure evil. They come to life even as anthropomorphic caricatures and that's a sign of brilliant writing.

The dialogue is the main strength of the game and is superbly written for the most part. There are great lines, lots of humor and tongue-in-cheek moments, horrible/amazing puns and it gets serious when needed.

Gameplay consists of gathering evidence and interviewing suspects and witness. Should you gather enough information regarding your case, you'll need to present in during the trial on court day by cross-examining the witlessness. Presenting the proper evidence at the proper time will sway the jury in your favor. Truth be told the gameplay mechanics are incredibly simple but I do believe that any further amount of complexity would deviate too much from the theme of the game. While it might appear fairly straightforward there are a few situation where you could fail a case so it's important to be thorough with your investigation.

There's a total of 4 acts to experience with the 4th having 3 possible endings depending on your actions on the 3rd. Acts are self-contained in their stories but also there are several recurring characters who will appear throughout the whole game.

I do however have a few minor complaints about the game. A personal pet peeve of mine was the lack of a 'on-the-spot' saving system. Instead the game saves after the end of a day. Not a huge gripe but a minor inconvenience in my book. I would also mention that if you skip a piece of dialogue by accident there's no way of going back to read since the game has no chat log so I would advice caution.

All in all, Aviary Attorney was a very pleasant experience for around 4 hours. The dialogue and characters are masterfully done and each moment of written dialogue with the anthropomorphic characters was pure delight. The gameplay elements might be simple but the game excels in creating an engaging story for the player. If you want a twist of the 'Ace Attorney' games, then Aviary Attorney is guaranteed to you keep you entertained.

[b]Aviary Attorney 3/5: [/b] Ptákovina. Doslova a do písmene. Herní satira formou jakože bajky s přenádhernou rytinovou stylizací, která zaujme na první dobrou. O to více, že herně jde o neskrývanou poantropomorfizovanou aluzi na Ace Attorney sérii. Tedy typ specifické hratelnosti, která na PC dosud nemá důstojného zástupce (pokud vůbec nějakého). A to, bohužel, platí i po Aviary Attorney, který se o to snaží; sympaticky, ovšem neúspěšně.

 V první moment zarazí, že ono se to u kultovní capcomácké série neinspiruje. Ono ji to každou svou mechanikou (i zvuky) nestydatě vykrádá. Jenom v opoznání horším a nedotaženějším provedení. Čili tam, kde se předobraz skládá ze tří složek (adventurní pasáž shromažďování stop a důkazů, obsáhlé dialogy ve stylu vizuálních novel a samozřejmě rozcupování výpovědí svědků během samotného soudního přelíčení), kdy každá je sama o sobě hrou sama o sobě, tak zde zbyla jen kostra tohoto konceptu. Čili adventurní část tu sice je, ale nic moc se v ní dělat nedá. Vizuální novela to je, ale taková, kdy vskutku jen neinteraktivně odklikáváte dialogy a nic více. A samotné přelíčení je průběhem i zvraty příliš nalajnované na to, aby měl člověk (ehm, pták) pocit, že opravdu musí zapojit mozek při vznášení námitek, argumentaci či předkládání důkazů.

 Navíc je to krátké (sotva čtyři hodiny, "originál" se v každém díle pohybuje v řádu desítek hodin), málo komplexní, přímočaré (nějaké větvení tu díky přelíčením je, ale dopad na průběh je spíše symbolický), nezamotané a co hůře působí to že tvůrcům došly finance z komunitního zafinancování. Výsledkem čehož je viditelně uspěchaný finální akt, aby to jakž takž vytvářelo alespoň nějaký náznak dějového oblouku a uzavření. Nedaří se to však a nechává si to otevřenou hradní bránu (ne, toto nejsou zadní vrátka) pro případné pokračování. Ono to vlastně ani nijak neskončí, jen se to v jednom momentě utne uprostřed děje a... A nic.

 Že dosavadní řádky, krom pochvaly stylizace a výběru žánru, jsou výrazně negativní? No ano, ale pak je tu jeden aspekt, který neradno podceňovat. Má to totiž výtečně napsané dialogy. Zapracování vyspělejších podtónů funguje, esence "lafontainovství" zvířecí Paříže na sklonku 18. století je podchycena přímo výtečně a škorpení ústředního dua nepůsobí nuceně. Ba dokonce je opravdu vtipné. Ostatně právě duo ptačích právníků je tím vůbec nejlepším, co tento titul nabízí. Zasloužilo by si být v lepší hře; respektive ve hře, která by navzdory svému okopírovanému konceptu byla důslednější a dotaženější v tom, o co se snaží.

33086753.review:
I loved the Ace Attorney series. It's a shame they aren't on Steam. Now that I've gotten that out of the way I bought this game looking for a familiar vibe. This game is all that and more. Even though the comparison is clear this game has it's own unique style and a couple of different mechanics that make it more evolved than it's lovable aforementioned cousin. 

Everything from the visual style and music all the way to some time management mechanics make Aviary Attorney a game all it's own. The setting and graphics remind me of a Piranesi painting. If you don't know who that is don't worry, just know the art is extremely detailed and works with the setting being 1840s France. The fact that the main cast are two well dressed dapper birds are characters that aren't quite endearing but at the same time are well animated through their dialogue and actions. There's definitely a lot of light hearted humor mixed in with all the evidence gathering and hard work that befalls an attorney. 

The real guts of this game is the time management before a trial. This is where things  can get a little tough. While most games of this kind tend to have a straightforward path in this game it's entirely possible for you to miss some evidence or lose a case. You have to manage your time before the trial wisely and make sure you're properly prepared for court. Losing sucks but life goes on and so does the game. You can also get penalized in court for wasting time with red herring questioning. I feel like that level of challenge makes you think a bit more strategically because if you only have 6 days before a case then you have to choose what is relevant to pursue. It really makes you think, but not too much. 

I've only played through the first 2 cases and so far I like what I see. It's a fresh take on the genre and adds some things that make it a different kind of animal. Definitely pick it up if you're into the Ace Attorney series. It's fresh, entertaining, and the writing's solid.

33022789.review:
I had a great time with this game. It is clearly influenced by the Ace Attorney series of games, and I feel like it has accomplished its own little place in the library of puzzling law games. It has its own unique quirks and style, with interesting characters and cases to play through. There's a lot I like about this game, and a few things I feel could be improved upon.

The theme and art style are really charming. It is set in 19th century France and you play as a falcon lawyer named Jayjay Falcon who is accompanied by his assistant, Sparrowson. Both characters are very fun to follow and see their dialogue and banter they have together. All of the characters being animals is a neat twist and gave everyone their own added flair of unique personalities. The hand-drawn art style was also very pleasant.

The game is witty and well-written, and the cases themselves are interesting. You spend the days before the trial doing your investigations and it is less linear than in Ace Attorney. You can unfold the case in different ways depending on where you investigate first and what choices you make. The game is unique in that each case can actually have a different outcome depending on what pieces of evidence you do and don't find, resulting in different endings for each case and different endings for the game. This is hindered slightly by the non-functioning save system. There is an option in the menu for saving & quitting, but the game doesn't save. The game only saves at the end of each day. The game still works well without this function, but it shouldn't be there if it does not work. Also, considering the cases have different outcomes, it would be nice to not only save whenever you'd like, but to have different save files to easily go back to try and go for a different outcome of a case. Especially since events in the third case affect the ending you receive. Although, this game does have replay value, so I don't think many people would have a problem going back and starting the cases from the beginning to see what other sorts of things they can do that they missed from their first play-through.

Another thing that's a bit of a negative is that there is no option to read through previously read dialogue. So if you accidentally skip through some, you cannot go back to read it. Other than the few nitpicky thing here and there, this game is a lot of fun for any Ace Attorney fan or mystery/puzzle fan in general. I really hope a sequel is in the works for Aviary Attorney.

I'm a sucker to classical music, and it blends perfectly into each scenarios.

Positives:
Great music, great art, great story. The sense of humor is on point, as is the sense of drama. It's technically possible to miss key evidence for each case, but in practice you're likely to get the important things and do well enough anyway.

Negatives:

30462648.review:
[h1] 4/5 Endearing characters, engaging story, but deeply unsatisfying endings [/h1]

First off, I want to say I had an absolute blast with this game. I loved playing with my friends and voicing all the characters with them. It was funny, tense, and unexpectedly sweet at times. It truly is one of the most fun games I've played in a long while.

I also like that you could fail a case, but still continue on with the story. And that bomb at the end of the first case? DAMN!

Unfortunately, the endings did not do the rest of the game justice. Don't get me wrong Act 4s A-C were also great, in their own way, but they all just... end. It feels like the writers just wanted to wrap up the game they had. So they cut off right after the climax with: [spoiler] "The revolution was a success and things happened" [/spoiler]

The lovely side characters you meet? Depending on what route you are on, you never meet them again. Wanna know the motives and backstories of the killer Inspector Volerti has been referencing this whole time? Too bad! Wham. Bam. Reveal.
Act 4 has great build up, which could've lent itself to great, dramatic moments but it feels like as soon as that point is reached the game ends. 

Also, the game gives you a feel of having a much more complex mechanic than it actually does.

[spoiler]Wanna let Cygne take the fall for Howl's murder? Reynard will only be mad at you until the next Act rolls around.
Fail Dame Caterline? Well, that was sure a thing that happened. Nothing you can do about it though![/spoiler]
The only case that really matters is at the end of Act 3.

All in all, I love the game but it deserved better endings.

30266643.review:
As someone who has spent $10 on a game where you date birds as a Japanese school girl whilst battling a world ending cult, I was expecting the same tone from Aviary Attorney. At first during the first case's investigation, it seemed like it but with more mystery and drama rather than nonstop bird antics.[spoiler] The game then took a very unexpected twist and dark turn as soon as the bomb of the first trial was dropped.[/spoiler] Immediately, I knew I was getting myself into something much more in-depth and emotional and so far I am extremely satisfied with the game.
Overall, I enjoyed the game with its memorable cast, witty humor, and well-crafted story. I can see myself playing it again and again just to read any text and watch any scenes i potentially missed.

30250586.review:
A wonderful visual novel with delightful visuals and music. Likeable characters and amusing dialogue bring together the several acts, keeping me engaged from start to finish. If you enjoy light hearted humour and puns then there will be no shortage of chuckles for you in Aviary Attorney.

I do have a few gripes. Namely: that you cannot go back to view previously read dialogue; that the third act hinges heavily upon a preset path of strict conditions to achieve the best ending; and that the fourth act ends up being extremely linear regardless of which path you end up in after the third act. The fourth act is less about the cases than the narrative, which is fine; but it felt me leaving a little deflated hoping for a real test of the attorney's lawyering skills and instead receiving a large amount of non-interactive character drama.

There is also one particular scene in the third act where the background art takes a horrible nosedive in quality during one of the most dramatic moments in the game. I understand there is only so much of Grandville's art to use for the narrative, but it clearly stands out amongst the masterpieces throughout the rest of the game.

[b]tl;dr[/b] With that said, the story was engaging regardless and though the game closes itself off in the latter half it was an enjoyable experience nonetheless. Maybe wait for a sale if you don't think 5-7 hours of lawyer drama is worth the asking price.

30128794.review: Fantastic art, fantastic story, a fun game.

30019839.review:
Aviary Attourney is a witty game heavily inspired by the Phoenix Wright series. Now gameplay wise, it's little more than a visual novel, lifting a lot of the "deductive" option choices from Phoenix Wright and leaving out much of the DS gimmick gameplay such as speaking into the console's microphone or blowing on the senser. Despite that, Aviary Attourney really holds up as an indie game of the genre because of its cleverly written plot that balances Phoenix-y humor with some surprisingly grounded themes of morality backed by some heavy outcomes based on your choices. The plot takes place in a semi-parodic version of 1848 France (so if the "touty, prissy Frenchy" setting is not your cup of tea, this game is not going to change anything) where everyone is some form of anthropomorphic Frenchman/woman. You lead a (Phoenix-y familiar) defense attourney trying to make a buck during a time when revolution is but a bulletshot away from erupting. Your decisions will determine the course of history in ths world and this is one of those few games where you decisions REALLY matter. It's perhaps the only game I've ever played that I felt absolutely compelled to play through every single ending and felt thoroughly rewarded for doing so. The devs have really gone through and made sure every single ending contributes heavily to the world building and subplot mysteries of this game. And for that, I found this game absolutely charming.

That being said...there are some technical issues. As of writing, the devs are working hard to fix a number of bugs for DRM free release. But when I played through the game, I had the game black-screen-crash on me about 5 times trying to get through a chapter. And there are few things to really dampen the experience of a mystery based visual novel type game than playing through the exact same plot drop five times. So bugs do exist and I don't know when they'll be fixed, but they definitely hurt the experience.

But...soon as those are fixed I thoroughly recommend this game for people who want a light-hearted game of animals in a pompous France trying to make a living even if it means the violent death of those who stand in your way. Or maybe not? That's up to you!

29471004.review:
First of all i should begin by saying that I enjoy story-driven games that present you with a movie-like experience.
I have played my fair shair of Telltale games, respectively.
Aviary Attorney shares some of the principles - you explore the world, collect clues and then are able to weave them into your dialogue options.
Unlike the Telltale games however, in Aviary Attorney, your choices actually do matter. I am not saying that you'd have a myriad of options, but if for example you investigate a crime scene and miss something, that particular clue will cause a line of reasoning in court go amiss.
You start as a defense Attorney and you are thrown into pre-revolutionary Paris where you go about and question witnesses, collect clues and then try to coherently present them in court.
The story is quite enjoyable, the humour is great and the art style is rather marvellous. 

If you, like me, enjoy immersion into strange worlds and stories but you can't afford the time to play through, let's say a Witcher, and you are ok with limited gameplay (in terms of player skill) then this game is definitely for you.
I wholeheartedly recommend this game - but make sure you check how much time the average player spends in this, as this is rather short (which I personally found quite pleasing).

29328299.review:
If you like Ace Attorney, this is a good alternate take on the court system. This game takes good advantage of its setting in revolutionary France for the overarching plot and theme. The investigation portions use a time system to visit locations. During my first run of the game, it never felt like I had enough time to visit every location and collect evidence. Combined with a save system that only lets you restart at the beginning of the day, that led to a frantic tension during the quick courtroom scenes where my case wasn't strong enough to always save my client. It's a nice difference to Ace Attorney's perfect cases that always go in your favor once deus ex machina hits. As you play through Aviary Attorney, you can revisit days to make better decisions and hopefully get a better ending for you clients...and yourself.

The only cons I had with the game was that the "Save & Quit" system didnt' always work, there were no control schemes for controllers, and during repeat plays, there was no easy way to skip through text quickly. These are petty annoyances, and I still enjoyed Aviary Attorney very much. The characters, setting, plot, and mechanics are all interesting.

29245951.review:
As you might have guessed its not quite Ace Attorney, although it styles itself after the series a bit.

While the game is a legal drama, there's not quite enough in this game to make it really robust like the Ace Attorney series.  There's a bit lacking in the way of courtroom back-and-forth that I had come to expect, and instead you have a time system which will lead a new player astray of the best ending due to being unsure how to complete everything in the allotted action limit.  This isn't necessarily bad as the 'bad' ending I got was still pretty satisfying, but it just means that the game seems to lack a little in content.  What's there is still pretty good.  Its understandably hard to match crazy japanese writing, and I'm guessing it wasn't quite what they were going for anyway.  It was my own expectations going into it.

The characters and story are fairly enjoyable and humorous, with a few good wall-breaking references thrown in that don't feel out of place.  The art and music, being taken from royalty free recordings and prints, works well for the setting and the game's menus and UI control well.

Its about 5 or so hours for a first time playthrough, maybe a bit more or less as my estimate is off from a partial 2nd playthrough.  I enjoyed myself, and I'd recommend it  It probably helps that I really like birds too.

29045732.review: An absolutely adorable, fun and absorbing game! Apart from the masterpiece graphics and classic music acting better than any form of narration, the game has a very innovative way of ending a crime investigation with a defense's point of view rather than the prosecutor's. And it's not only about showing the evidence you've gathered! The best part of each trial is the cross-examination where you get to nit-pick at the words of the witnesses and form your own theories, some convincing (ones that buy you the heads-up from the jury) and some totally fantastical (which might end up ruining the trial completely). These trials test your wits far more than your point-and-click abilities and inspire some real stress, as well as fulfillment once the trial is won! The background (revolutionary France) and the story are well-crated. And the characters are very adorable and convincing. This game is a solid 9/10, I'd give it 10/10 if it was a bit longer - say 10 trials at least. I really hope there's a sequel coming!

28998233.review:
I really loved this game. It's great for Ace Attorney fans, and I think should be great for non-Ace Attorney fans as well. Obviously, it's a visual novel, so don't expect much gameplay. 

While this game is clearly a love letter to Ace Attorney, it attempts to stand out on its own too, and I believe it does that really well. The art style is really interesting, and really nice. The music is appropriate to the art style as well and gives the whole game a really nice atmosphere. 

The dialogue is mostly what you'd expect from Ace Attorney. Doesn't take itself too seriously most of the time, but from time to time it'll get there. It's mostly silly stuff that you can expect. There's a couple references I don't totally like (Most are references to Ace Attorney, but I find that's acceptable considering the whole game is meant to be a love-letter to it.) but the references are very very few and mostly harmless.

Where as Modern Ace Attorney games are absolutely filled to the brim with horrible filler and unskippable flashbacks, I actually wish this game had a bit more. I think this game was desperately in need of a third case before the final one to really get a sense of the game and the characters in it, and honestly, I just wanted more stuff in general. 

The first two cases are probably the best, as they're a lot shorter and a lot more focused. The last case isn't bad by any means, but it can get a bit off track at times, and due to there being multiple endings, it might have caused some other endings to feel less fleshed out and finished. It's still a great time, however. Like I said, the only real con with this game, I just wish there was more. 

One last very slight issue, there's not exactly a fast forward button. towards the end, you'll be wanting to see the different endings, because they are quite different and a bit lengthy, but there's no fast forward button. It's easy enough to click through everything rapidly, BUT it woulda been nice to just have a fast forward button either way. Like I said, very slight issue. 

Anyway, for 15 bucks, I'd say it's very worth it for a nice cozy visual novel. I got about 9 hours of it, and got all the endings, so I'd say that's pretty decent. I believe this game only goes on sale about once a year and its only 5 dollars off, so its up to you if you want to wait for it or not, but I think 15 is a great price. 

I'm really hoping for a sequel. We could certainly do with more lawyer/mystery games that isn't filled to the brim with useless filler like the new Ace Attorney games are these days.

A delightful, witty game with:

- wonderful artwork (based on and taken from the work of J. J. Grandville)
- a great story with some basic insight into court proceedings and principles
- loveable and lovingly-loathable characters
- classic music that fits perfectly
- puns a-plenty!

Even though there is no audio for the dialogue, it's fun to read out loud with a friend and create voices for each character.  If you have no friends this game will make you feel like you do, and you can still speak the screenplay in your head!  Basic sound effects are used to enhance feelings or add to the punnery!

Albeit a short game, it's time and money well spent.  Just looking at the artwork while listening to the music (and acquiring the occasional ticklish chuckle) is worth it for me!

28771009.review:
Aviary Attorney is like Ace Attorney, except with animals. In Aviary Attorney you play as a bird named Falcon with your assistant Sparrowson solving murder cases. 

Pros
- Pretty good story
- Loveable chracters, Sparrowson in particular is really charming to listen to 
- All of the endings are pretty good and satisfying 
- Neat presentation that perfectly captures the time period the game is based on
- Well done music that, again fits with the game's time period
- Most realistic cross-examination I've seen in a lawyer game that Im aware of and is quite fun
- Interesting day mechanic, although kind of frustrating at points

Cons
- Pretty short, it took 7 hours to beat the game and the game costs $16.99
- I guess this point is based entirely on varying mileages but, the game overall was pretty easy, I only struggled on case 3 [spoiler](although due to the multiple endings, with one of them requiring you to fail the third trial... That's debateable)[/spoiler]
- The day mechanic makes no sense to me, you can spend an entire day at one location having a conversation and spend a day there, but you can go there again and have a slightly shorter conversation and not waste a day, it's not that I hate the mechanic it's just that it makes no sense to me
- There was some static with loading screens that lagged, but that's just a nitpick
- Can't skip entire events instead you have to keep on clicking, which becomes very tedious when replaying the game

Overall, I really liked Aviary Attorney. However, I'd recommend getting the game on sale because $16.99 is pretty pricey considering the length of the game. Regardless, it was fun, charming and a delight. I'd give it a 7/10. Kudos to Otter Guy for gifting this to me. :3

28206516.review:
WARNING: Some slight Spoilers are written in the Review!
NOTE: This Game takes as Inspiration the Ace Attorney Series, hence I will compare it furthermore in my Review with said Series

Aviary Attorney puts you into the Role of Private Defense Attorney "JayJay Falcon" with his Assistant "Sparrowson". 

The Setting is set in France 1848. 
The World itself is depicted like the Reality, so all past/present Events (and to some Degree also Persons) are real in this Game.

Like the Ace Attorney Series, the Acts begins with a Request to defend/meet someone. From there starts the Investigation for Clues/Evidences before the Trial Day comes. 

You carry a Wallet with some Money for buying/bribing Persons for Info/Evidences. If you solve Cases, you get Payment. Otherwise you can earn Money by playing a Card Game in the Student Tavern.

When the Investigation begins, there are 2 major differences:

1) Visiting Places costs Time (1 Day) and sometimes you cannot visit all places for a Search. Choosing wrong Places or simply waste Time will end with not enough Evidence for the Trial. This can result in a GUILTY Verdict for the defending Client. In the Ace Attorney Series, the Game will only let you proceed if you have collected everything possible.

2) Throughout the Game you will be faced with many Decisions to be made. Most of the Decisions will alter the Story and influence where you will end in the last Act. In the Ace Attorney Series, the Outcome is always the same, so you cannot influence the Story at how it proceeds.

Unlike the Ace Attorney Games you can lose the Game for not having enough Evidences before Trial or/and choosing wrong Answers/Decisions. You can always reload an Act and even pick the desired Day, so no skipping endless Texts until you reach a Decision Point.

The Courtroom Part is nearly identical. Witness will state a Testimony -> Cross Examination -> find the Objection hidden in the Testimony -> rinse and repeat until final Verdict from Judge and Jury.

Here are some of my + / o / - Points:

Positive:
-Fantastic Artwork and Designs, which gives off a "Classy" Atmosphere
-Good Orchestral Soundtrack which fully supports the Art Design
-Serious Story with dark Undertones
-Funny Sidekick which assists the Protagonist in many different Ways
-Most Animals have Jobs or Personality which supports/contradicts their Character (Example: A Donkey as an arrogant all-knowing Librarian, A Fox who works as a cunning Private Investigator, etc.)
-Decisions during In-game can alter the Story and its End (3 different Endings)
-Finding Errors in Witnesses Testimony through Evidence are logically built
-Many Possibilities to gather Evidence/Infos through Gifts, Bribing, etc.
-Visiting Places costs Time, therefore making it crucial to decide where to go next
-It's possible to lose Cases if not enough Evidences are gathered
-Possibility to load previous Acts and all of its Days!
-Card Game for earning more Money

Neutral:
-No Possibility to access Inventory, etc. while on the City Map
-You can earn more Money through playing a Game at the Student Tavern to avoid Shortage, but it's not that difficult if you keep winning the Cases
-Casual Cinematics which can be accessed from the City Map (only on specific Points and optional), can sometimes contain Spoiler
-French Words/Places/Persons can sometimes be confusing
-No Steam Overlay

Negative:
-Only 4 Acts
-Short Duration of the Game (5-8 Hours)
-Memory Leak Bug during my Play (Fullscreen)
-No Skip Button during Texts if you want to reach certain Points
-Some Decisions (Example: Tell Truth/Lie) aren't really Decisions, since Sparrowson will interrupt if choosed wrong and decide the "right" Course

Fazit:
What caught me primarily, was the Artdesign. I love it and the Characters inhabiting this alternate World.
Ace Attorney Fans will get a familiar but very different Experience. 
My real Negative Point, was the short Duration for this Game. Could have been longer, but just take it as it is.
For those who like also Visual Novels with Decisions, can't make a bad "Decision" with this Game ;)

27929684.review:
If you enjoyed Ace Attorney, GET THIS GAME.

This game is certainly niche.  I doubt anyone was clamoring for a furry procedural game set in revolutionary France based off of a charicaturist's sketches and period classical music.  And yet..!

It's definitely made in the vein of Ace Attorney, but it also goes out of its way to turn the genre on its head at times, and even gives a bit of a branching plot depending on whether you win or lose the cases (and yes, you can lose a case and continue the story!)  But I truly admire the story Sketchy Logic has put together with the elements they chose.  The art, music, setting, and gameplay all manage to tie into each other for the story, which has surprising depth for its brevity.  

My only complaint about the game is that there is not more of it, which is a happy complaint to have.  And even then, I felt very satisfied by the game as a whole as I watched the credits.  Anyone who enjoys the time period, Ace Attorney-styled games, or even examples as games as an artistic medium should give this one a go.  I loved it.

26549301.review:
This game was actually really great! It's basically Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney but everybody is some kind of animal. It's also got a bit of a challenge in the "New Day" system. Some areas that you can explore sometimes take a full day to completely search, and that can sometimes lead to your benefit, or otherwise. Unlike Ace Attorney, this game progresses whether you have everything for the case or not, so you can go into a court trial and not have anything to suit your case and the jury in the end will decide whether your client is guilty or not, which is another unique feature. If you do well during the trial, you'll occasionally get to see the Jury discussing the case so far, and depending on if you BS your way through the trial or not will determine how the case will go in the end. If you miss a crucial piece of evidence however, the game thankfully allows you to reload to different days as well. The game also has multiple endings which I love about it. I've only gotten one out of the few however so I don't know how else it ends. 

With a great soundtrack, amazing story, lovable characters, and a wonderful art design, this game is a must if you love the Ace Attorney Series.

26365543.review:
Absolutely genius and fun!

Well-written scirps: terse and humorous. I have not finished all cases but I guess each case's ending contributes to the final ending. Lots of choices, and if you fail in one day's investigation, you can always load it and try again. I guess there are at least 2 endings of each case. I was shocked by the twist of the 1st case, when I thought I was clever and got all puzzles solved. In each case file, you will encounter twists more than once, which is extremely fun.

Moreover, the writer has farther sights than detective stories. You will be involved in the French Revolution in one way or another, depending on your choices. You can feel that the writer takes a stand close to Hugo, with lots of sympathy towards the lower class. Sense of justice is precious. The debate of what is justice is well carried out in this game.

Anyway, enjoyed every minute playing it. I will certainly play it more than once, to experience the different conscequences produced by my choices.

25315035.review:
There's a lot to like about this game. The art and design are whimsical and wonderful. The music is great. Most importantly, it made me laugh, a lot. (Yes, most of the humor is corny.) 

Unfortunately, for me, the negatives are big enough that they overwhelm the positives. I bought and played the game well after its initial release, so I didn't deal with the whole mess of the game being released in incomplete form, although that's definitely not a plus for Sketchy Logic. My biggest problems with the game are:
-- The abrupt tone shift 2/3 of the way through the game, combined with almost completely railroaded writing. There are lots of choices that would appear to be poignant, and the game description says "Decisions have consequences!" -- but it turns out that only two or three decisions in the entire game actually do have any effect on the game or the endings. Then, after playing a relatively lighthearted story for a few hours, suddenly you end up in something much more grim and gritty. Also, the main characters' behaviors stop making any sense, and your "choices" don't even maintain the illusion of story impact. 
-- There are multiple endings, but replaying is much more difficult than it needs to be. There's an option to go back to previous saves, but it's clunky and I'm not convinced of its accuracy. There's also no real option for speeding through cinemas or dialogue.
-- The game is very short for the price. I don't mind this in games where the experience is short but high-quality. This isn't one of those games.

The game's worth a few bucks for the laughs, the art, and the music.

25168471.review:
I won't enjoy writing this review.

First, I'll talk about what I like about the game. The art style is gorgeous. The characters are... distinct. Yeah, I'll stick with that. The first case is passable. But it goes downhill from there.
EDIT: also the music is amazing.

Now to talk about what I don't like. The branching path endings are basically to tack on more content. None of the multiple endings are interesting or all that well developed for me to care about. The characters are not memorable at all. While eccentric like in the Ace Attorney series, they aren't much beyond that. Their motives are simply and don't lead to any greater thought or speculation. Having animals as the "people" is amusing for the first 20 seconds.

The main character is a block of wood. Absolutely forgettable. They try to give him some intrigue as he has a reason why he changed his name... but I'll just tell you it's really lame. Not going to spoil it for you, but it's weak.

The side-bird is a block of wood... but with a flower painted on it. He's not interesting, but he tells some Dad jokes that are sometimes amusing. The effect they use to draw attention to his jokes gets tired after the first or second time they use it.

The main prosecutor is reminiscent of Miles Edgeworth of the Ace Attorney series, but lacks meaningful character development. If they developed him a bit more, I'd love him.

The investigation setup is gimmicky. Budgeting time makes sense. However, it is bullshit because knowing what you will need to do on a certain day requires miraculously looking into the future and knowing what testimonies will come up. No days can be wasted. And in the last chapter, they basically just tell you where to go. The court sections are way too simple. Rarely does it require more than two brain cells and a few pieces of evidence to advance. Whereas in Ace Attorney, these were marathons of presenting evidence and actually figuring things out. 

I often compare this game to Ace Attorney because that's where this game draws a lot of inspiration from. And in nearly all respects, it falls flat on its face.

I really wanted to like this game. An Ace Attorney-like game on Steam was a dream come true. With BIRDS!

But sadly, this game is okay at best. They should have focused on making one cohesive narrative with better developed characters instead of a branching paths system with bland characters.

Rating: 6/10

24437247.review:
Quite the charming little game, Aviary Attorney was a very short, but sometimes hilarious, sometimes profound venture into an anthromorphic Paris of the mid-19th century. Sparrowson is at the heart of most of this hilarity, so it should come with no surprise that I felt his presence most acute and most memorable, from the puns (oh they are many in number) to his obsession with food; and for that, even a bumbling lackey as he may be, and for all the other slightly forgettable characters which come and go, I can only express my absolute approval and recommendation of this game. 
--

I'll try not to dillydally, so huge disclaimer: I've never played Ace Attorney. Therefore, I cannot speak from the perspective of an AA veteran on its relative difficulty, and what features it might borrow or drop.

The game moves quickly, and it will progress with or without you. There's a city map to travel around to gather your clues in your own free time, but if you miss something critical—tough luck. I enjoyed this aspect, as much as I'm sure others might be infuriated by it. It was one way to force critical thinking, even if one needn't wade far from the shallow end to arrive at the correct conclusion. Aside from that, it is pretty standard and the trial process is very easy to understand for a novice defense attorney such as myself. It's also quite convenient that time stops whenever you need to make an important decision (how I wish that was the case in real life).

Visuals and sound is famously crafted from public domain, so if you enjoy the works of J.J. Grandville, and the romantic pieces of Camille Saint-Saëns and his contemporaries, then this department should warrant no further scrutiny. I'm sure you'd not be reading this if none of that appealed to you in the first place.

So in short, Con(s): Short! (Seven hours approx. between multiple endings and a sizeable AFK session), and (for the most part) Easy; the story is intriguing and fun-filled, but the few cases you do get liberty in are only difficult because you run out of time trying to acquire a piece of evidence in a specific order, or on a particular date.

Pro(s): Everything else, honestly. Music, art, writing, characters and their interactions all play a crucial part in creating this charming atmosphere, plus they're all so GOD DAMN ADORABLE.

24003588.review:
THE PREAMBLE: This is a short and relatively simple lawyering adventure game, clearly inspired by that other lawyering adventure game. Enough has been said about the art and music, so this review will just cover the bits that aren't obvious from screenshots.

THE GOOD: Excellent characterization and a very polished story. Some choices from previous cases have an impact on future ones. The puzzles are very straightforward and logical; no extreme leaps of logic are required (but see below). There are three possible endings.

THE BAD: Gameplay isn't up to the standards of its inspiration. The designers have attempted to "fill the gaps" by introducing time-management and money-management mechanics, but this has the side effect of punishing the player for not knowing ahead of time where to go and what to do, even though it is not always obvious. The trials are extremely short; there's only one multi-day trial. In general, the game is a bit too easy; there are virtually none of the "aha!" moments which are the mark of a really good adventure-game puzzle. 

THE VERDICT: This bird is a little undernourished, but still worth the price, especially if you appreciate a well-crafted yarn and don't mind a lack of challenge. Let's hope that the creators' next offering turns out somewhat meatier, though.

23609063.review:
This game is definitely worth a shot if you're a fan of Phoenix Wright or visual novels in general. The game's whole aesthetic is fantastic, combining unique visuals, a well thought-out setting, and solid writing that's at turns both funny and chilling. The court cases themselves will probably feel a little too short and simple for veterans of the Ace Attorney franchise, but the (sometimes unforgiving) time limits in the investigation phase provide an extra challenge that helps make up for it. The game is also more than willing to let you lose your cases, which both ups the stakes a tad and provides some extra replay value in getting all of the trials' possible outcomes. The branching cases at the end are also executed well; I've only played two so far but I'm impressed by how different they are. Too many times visual novels bost "multiple endings" that barely differ, but this one actually delivers. 

I only noticed two small issues. There was a slight saving glitch that made me replay part of the second case (without a fast forward button). There were also a couple of continuity errors that appeared when I lost some of the trials (most notably, a witness from the first trial that recognizes you and references events of the first trial, even if you intentionally blow the trial before he even shows up.) Neither hiccup was major, though.

Overall I enjoyed the game and would love to see more from its developers.

23605270.review: If you like games like "Phoenix Wright", this should be right up your alley. The format is very similar, you are an attorney who defends clients by looking for evidence, questioning witnesses, and then presenting your findings in court. The cases feel a bit easier than anything in that game, but thanks to the art style, silly humor, and great music, there is more than enough charm to carry you through a playthrough. It would have been nice if it were slightly more challenging, but I personally enjoyed it immensely and hope they make a sequel. GRADE: B+

23594023.review:
In 1840s France, two birds investigate a series of escalating crimes that lead them to the heart of the revolution. AA is a visual novel with court-scene puzzle sections, where you have to present your case by choosing the right evidence in order to win the jury’s favour. What I love about this game is it strikes the perfect balance between serious and silly. Yes, the characters are all anthropomorphic animals (a lion smoking a pipe anyone?), and puns are lavished throughout courtesy of Sparrowson, (usually accompanied by a world-weary sigh from Monsieur Jayjay Falcon). 

But the dialogue is well-written, and the characters and crimes are ones you end up genuinely caring about. The deeper you get, the more you realise you are being played. And what’s best about the game is the way it comes down to making a choice between doing the right thing, being a good lawyer, and keeping yourself out of trouble. You’re racing the clock to get the evidence you need and piece together a water-tight case, but ultimately the truth is much harder to find. 

I actually have nothing negative to say about AA.

[url=http://actionwillhaveconsequences.tumblr.com/post/145519900420/3-on-a-theme-detectives]Original review on tumblr[/url]

23004178.review: I absolutely loved Aviary Attorney and would recommend it to anyone.  Funny and exceptionally clever, AA creates a really entertaining journey with exceptionally few moving parts.  A measure of how good it is -- my wife, who has never played any computer games whatsoever (and never showed an interest in them) sat down with me and we played the whole game together, laughing all the way through. It was just too entertaining to miss -- even to someone who doesn't like games.  I've read a couple of snooty and entitled negative reviews (I'm looking at you, hardcoregamer.com) that I can't make any sense out of: pound for pound, I think that along with 'Kentucky Route Zero' this is the most fun you can have playing a micro-budget indie game. 22849502.review:
Being an avid lover of birds and pretty fond of murder mysteries, I've wanted to play this for a while! I finally got to playing (and finishing) this lovely piece of a visual novel and I very much recommend it to anyone who'd appreciate being a bird-brained lawyer with a sweet-tooth.

The visuals and audio are fantastic and well-executed, using work by 19th-century French caricaturist J. J. Grandville and adaptations of French romantic-era music. The atmosphere is absolutely charming. There's plenty of amusing dialouge and the great amount of colorful characters there is to interact with is refreshing.

Unfortunately, it's a rather short game, even with all the alternate outcomes, and not very difficult. There are also some choices that are hit-and-miss on whether they'll do anything other than empty out your in-game wallet just for the hell of it, which is a little disappointing since some people might need that money to get certain endings.

Also, the constant bombardment of bird-puns is amazing; they made me want to cry more than any of the deaths or plot twists ever could.

Overall Aviary Attorney is an incredibly fun and intriguing court drama visual novel in the style of the Ace Attorney game series. The game oozes charm with it's witty writing and unique visual style making it quite an enjoyable and entertaining playthrough. Unfortunately even with 3 different endings the game is short and only clocks in at 6-8 hours max, plus its puzzles are fairly easy to solve. If you are a fan of the Ace Attorney series you will definitely enjoy the familiar gameplay and well crafted story. I myself am eager for additional cases and endings down the line. However, if you are turned off by Aviary Attorney's shortness and easy difficulty you may want to wait and pick it up on sale.

Pros:
+ The story is well crafted and entertaining, with three incredibly varied endings.
+ The writing is witty and well done. 
+ The visuals and sound are beautiful.
+ An incredible cast of characters.
+ The courtroom and crime scene investigation gameplay is just as fun as the Ace Attorney series.

Cons:
- The game is short. It took me only 4 hours on my first playthrough and 6 hours to see every ending. 
- There is little replay value after completing all endings, save to make different choices for a few minor plot changes.
- Easy courtroom and investigation puzzles. I had no problem procuring all necessary evidence on my first playthrough and faltered only once or twice in presenting wrong evidence.

Recommended

Rating: 8/10
