21732465.review:
Taken by itself, this game is alright.  Stick with me, there's more to this, or this would be a thumbs-up.  

There's a good narrative, but the gameplay suffers for it.  The gameplay is immaterial for the first half of the game; while it's true that winning or losing a trial affects the game, it's a cosmetic difference in the end.  Nothing actually changes, you're not locked into or out of any ending.  There's a lot of promise here, with the time passing mechanic, the ability to miss evidence and lose lose trials and continue, and having a jury to convince, but the game shifts narrative gears after two cases and that opportunity is squandered.

My other big complaint is that the game deliberately attempts to evoke Ace Attorney, and does a poor job in practice.  The gameplay is incredibly shallow; you never have more than a couple handfuls of evidence, and the contradictions should be incredibly easy to spot for any veteran of the series.  The most likely thing to trip you up is the time mechanic.  It's also short.  I've got 4.4 hours on record; that's how long it takes to beat the game and get every ending.

Truth be told, this would probably be better without what feels like a token amount of gameplay.  The narrative is interesting, and if you're looking for a good short story you could do worse.  However, you will likely leave very disappointed if you're looking for gameplay of Ace Attorney caliber, as I was, which is why this is getting a negative review.

A marvelous game that scratches that Ace Attorney itch almost perfectly.  Combining fantasic visuals, fitting classical music, and witty writing, Aviary Attorney is a must for AA fans who wouldn't mind seeing some new stories with new faces.  Their are some new mechanics to play around with too.  Managing time and money adds to the stress of defending your clients, though I feel that the features lacked some depth.  The addition of a jurist system makes perfect sense and works well from a gameplay perspective as well.

That's not to there aren't faults though.  The game is a tad short, with none of the cases being terribly long (though that's not to say they aren't difficult at times).   Expect to see lots of returning characters and locations between cases as well (surely a result  of being a Kickstarter funded infie game).  I got the feeling that the game felt like an outstanding first step into a potential franchise, one that would hopefully have more funding for longer cases with more characters, places, and writing.

21656909.review:
Sparrowson and Jayjay Falcon, the eponymous aviary attorneys, live in a version of 19th Century Paris populated by animals. The gameplay very much resembles Ace Attorney‘s, with the player taking control of the game’s protagonists to investigate crime scenes, interview witnesses, and gather evidence as they work their way through the duo’s cases. While the core mechanics remain the same throughout the game’s story, the overarching narrative will take you beyond the courtroom and into the bowels of Paris where revolution is brewing.

The game’s visual style and sound are both fantastic, uniquely making use of actual artistic works from the period now available in the public domain. For those who have played Aviary Attorney, an image search of artist J. J. Grandville’s name will show a lot of familiar characters who have been faithfully represented within the game. The use of composer Camille Saint-Saëns’s works adds a congruity to the game’s sonic identity that greatly enhances the experience.

Solving the cases is mentally stimulating, and there are a few different endings for each case depending on the choices you make as you progress. The game’s plot is intriguing and features a satisfying amount of twists and turns that pulls you into the story. And of course, the game is just really damn funny. If you like terrible bird puns, I’d highly recommend giving Aviary Attorney a look.

"What thoughts do you have in this bird feathered brain of yours"?

Ever wanted to be a lawyer in pre-revolution paris of 1840? Ever wanted to be a bird too? Maybe both at the same time? Well, Aviary Attorney gives you the chance.

In nicely drawn backgrounds Sketchy Logic let´s the animal kingdom have free reign in the courtyard, when the player takes over the role of JayJay Falcon, Attorney at his majestys court.
Beginning harmlessly enough, with day to day murderers, JayJays way brings him on the brink of revolution and on death´s door himself. All the while only relaying on his falcon beak sharp mind and the wit of his trusty sidekick Sparrowson.

While the gameplay itself is basically a visual novel, including finding and combining clues, using them at court and interrogation, it also offers some different paths, where you´re decisions or even lack of finding every clue will count.
The cases are fun to play through and the story is engaging enough, to even try to get some different endings.
Undeniable the best part of the game though is the humor, which the dialogues are full of.

The setting is, as written earlier visually and musically very nicely done. The backgrounds show some of Paris most famous sites and are well drawn, as well as the character art. While there is no real speech, each character has it´s own way of sound, while speaking, a small, fun detail, which enhances the atmosphere even further, when the wolf and lion sound much "stronger" than the little rabbit.

Conclusio:
I had much fun with Aviary Attorney and if you´re interested in the setting, bird jokes, Attorney and/or VN games etc. this game is surely worth a try. Can´t say much bad about it honestly.

Point Scale: 8/10

Short, but very enjoyable. Plays very much like the Ace Attorney series, including the silly dialogue paired with serious subject matter, but goes out of its way to subvert expectations as quickly as the first chapter.

Unlike the Ace Attorney games, the story branches at various points depending on your actions, so you can complete cases but not get the most satisfactory results. Your limited time to investigate means you may get locked out of evidence simply by visiting the wrong locations to many times. Thankfully, the game allows you to reload any previous day so you can retry small parts of each case as you please.

It's on the easy side - if you've completed a single Ace Attorney game you'll effortlessly pick the right options and only get hung up if you've failed to collect all the evidence.

Nonetheless, it's absolutely worth a try for a short story that offers a handful of twists.

21242963.review:
A very charming take on the Ace Attorney-style gameplay. With a refreshing, underused setting of 19-th century France, beautiful artwork by J. J. Grandsville, and a musical score that ranges from whimsicall to outright epic, Aviary Attorney turns into an experience thatI had no idea that I had wanted previously. 

For those who aren't familiar with the Ace Attorney-style detective games, here's a brief introduction: The main characters ar edefense atorneys, who have a new case brought upon them with each chapter. In the alloted days leading up to the trial, they must travel about the city in search of evidence so that their defendant may walk free from impending incarceration. The unique gameplay element that Aviary Attorney introduces is the ability to fail a case and have the story progress in spite of it. Because of this, the game allows you to re-load any given day within a chapter so the player may make new decisions and achieve a different outcome. This is really handy, considering that there are several subplots that can develop differently over the course of the first three chapters.

One of my favorite additions this game brings to the genre is its sense of scale. Aviary Attorney takes place in a society on the cusp of revolution. The meta-narrative of the game is presented not only in some of the major cases, but also in optional cutscenes that not only flesh out the world, but do so in a manner that helps present the story in a manner akin to a noir television serial.
Within the three possible endings you can achieve, it's very interesting to see how our characters will eveolve along with the plot. There's welcome character growth within each route that builds on previous cases in a different way. It's definitely one of the best introductions of consequence in a murder-mystery game.

This game is definitely worth it's price if you're itching for a new murder mystery series to explore.With the added ability to fail a given trial and have the story go on despite it, the game's ability to re-load any individual day of a case allows for an unexpected ammount of replayability. Fans of mystery novels, the French revolutionary period, and witty humor should definitely crack this one open!

21194732.review:
Okay, so this is probably my first actual review of a game. I'm writing this to show my genuine appreciation for this lovely piece of work.

And what a piece of work it is. I expected it to just be a jokey game full of puns and without anything big beyond the gimmick of animal people and avian lawyers. If you decide to buy and play it, you might expect Avian Attorney to be just that based on the first five, maybe ten minutes of play. I - and you, if you follow my train of thought - could not be more wrong. I won't go into details to avoid spoiling parts of the game, but it utterly gripped me. 

The characters you're supposed to like are likeable, the characters you ought to hate make themselves out to be absolute scum of the earth based on their in-game actions. It's all very believable as well, the plot and subplots seamlessly and smoothly hurry onward while you frantically make sense of courtroom law and procedure.

The game will last you about five hours if you do some reloading and read most of the text. More if you explore every path (I can recommend trying all three endings, they're amazing and very different from one another), less if you skip through it (don't). Expect to play it in one or two sittings, it's very hard to put the game down. 

If a sequel or some other similar game by this studio appears I'm buying it as soon as possible. It's just quality, dammit.

21192431.review:
If you’ve ever played an Ace Attorney game and wonder why there couldn’t be cute talking animals and French cultural references, Aviary Attorney is the game for you. In it, you play the role of JayJay Falcon,a somewhat unsuccessful defense attorney who finds himself in the employ of a menagerie of strange clients and you will need to call upon the efforts of your tireless assistant Sparrowson and your own critical-thinking skills in order to win each trial.

Aviary Attorney plays like any visual novel game with an inventory system, meaning that you will spend a good deal of the game reading dialogue and exploring different areas. The overall tone is comedy with a dash of seriousness to keep things interesting in between all the puns and deadpan humor and the game features three different endings depending on decisions made in the 3rd act.

All in all, I found this game to be pretty entertaining albeit not super challenging (the clues are fairly easy to figure out for most cases). Consider buying it if you’ve played the aforementioned Ace Attorney games and are looking for a way to scratch that itch.

21166416.review:
A lighthearted delight for fans of handsome birds and courtroom dramas alike. While I've never played the Ace Attorney games myself, I'm told this one draws a lot from those, with its own twists on the formula. You gather evidence through interviews and exploration of the crime scene and other places, stretching the role of what a defence attorney really does, and then you'll be given the chance to use that evidence against in the courtroom during cross-examinations by clicking on the part of a witness' statement you're able to contradict. It's simple, and not especially difficult, but it's fun and satisfying to work out and the developing storylines are entertaining and well-written, even if they can be predictable at times. 

It's all just so irresistibly charming, with a witty sense of humour and a colourful cast of characters. The art style, which literally just involves pasting animal heads onto 1800's paintings, looks sharp and distinct and really helps you immerse yourself in this seemingly alternate-history 1840's France. The main cast makes for a memorable pair, and I was frankly sad to have to see them go when I finished up the game. Though it's all over pretty fast, it's a satisfying journey and can end in multiple ways, with three entirely distinct final chapters depending on your choices in the third act, all of which can come to different conclusions.

With the multiple finales to be explored, there's actually a pretty good amount of content here, even if I found some of the finales more interesting than others. One was just what I wanted, the other was surprisingly good even if it started out a bit grim, and the third just seemed a little too dark and out of tone with the rest of the game. Despite that, they were all fun to explore and worth playing through, even if sometimes their endings felt a bit abrupt. 

I really can't think of anything I disliked about this one, other than it being a bit short and sometimes not entirely clear where you should go to find your clues. It's possible to miss important pieces of evidence by failing to visit the places you can find them or screwing something up when you get there, and if you do manage to fail a case, the story continues on rather than making you replay it, which is good but I can imagine would be a lot less satisfying an experience. Though it might be funny to play it again and fail the early cases on purpose just to see what happens. 

If you're a fan of visual novel kinds of things, and like murder mysteries and courtroom antics, then I hope you'll enjoy this one as much as I did.

21165684.review: I first bought tAvian attorney due to the humor factor and was pleasantly surprised at how well written and clever it was. The ways in which the different outcomes are achieved and the dialogue systems were well thought out. The storylines that were finished that is... sadly when you achieve one of the main story branches it states that the path is not yet finished and you have to step back a few days and try a different course of action. Not a good selling point for a supposedly non-early access game. That aside the game achieves what it sets out to do, create an Avian parody of Ace attorney. Mechanically the game works great. You travel around Paris in order to collect evidence and defend your client. There are several different locations you can travel to but traveling to most locations takes a whole day and you only have a certain amount of days before you must appear in court. This puts contraints on what you can do which makes matters seem more pressing. Avian Attorney really pushes you to actually investigate rather than blow money gambling on black jack (which is totally an option). the nice thing is if you missed a crucial piece of evidence you can always step back a day to get the ending you want. as I mentioned above the dialogue is also well written. There are so many different approaches you can take to obtain different forms of evidence or get past obstacles. will you bribe them or persuade them or just threaten to beat the shit out of them? the shear variety of choice within what is a relatively short storyline is the main draw for this game, well.. that and the glorious amount of Bird puns. all-in-all I give the game an 8/10 purely for being unfinished and me wanting even more of it! Although seemingly a simple novelty game at first sight Avian Attorney proves itself to be a fun and interesting ride for those who enjoy investigative games.  A tip though, if you find yourself stumped? just WING it. ha ha.. get it... Ill show myself out...

Recommended, with a slight reservation (cost). For reference, I got through to ending B, and thought the ending couldn't get anymore perfect, so I stopped there.

Anyways, Aviary Attorney is a charming, funny little game about anthropomorphic animals back in the Pre-Revolution days of France. You follow to main characters, the sardonic Jayjay Falcon and his quirky sidekick Sparrowson as they navigate through four trials whose destinations I will not spoil.

You go around the city collecting evidence from various sites, but before you start thinking this is Ace Attorney, there is a time limit, with many places requiring a full day to visit. With only days allowed for trials, it creates and interesting dilemma where not only do you have to figure out the best way to argue your client's case, but you have to find the most efficient path to getting the evidence you need, a path which is partially obscured to you. 

In the trial itself, things roll simply enough. You spot inconsistincies during cross examinations, pikcing up pieces of evidence for the jury to ogle that contradicts what they said. This is a strange game, in that there seems to be ways to partially lose your cases, or at least, not completely win them. TThankfully, I did, but I saw playthroughs afterwards where people did not and still got through the story.

As for the characters and the plot, I loved the characters, the dialogue, and again, Storyline B is where I stopped playing because I simply thought that end was the best one for all parties involved. As you may have noted from my explanation, there is a crucial point in the story where you end up with three different ending trials. I rather liked the idea, but it also ties into my one problem with the game, to be exaplained after I talk about aesthetic.

The aesthetic was quite good, I especially like the artwork, and the music was very well done for the period it was set in. I really have no complaints here, beecause as someone who loves aesthetics done differently (Journey, Transistor, Darkest Dungeon, etc)  I give a gold star to hand drawn art and music that fits the topic at hand.

The only problem I have is cost. If you're like me and get the best ending right off the bat, you may feel no need to go on to discover the other two. This can lead to you clocking only a minute amount of hours in. However, I do like short games, so I can only complain so much, but buyer beware.

All in all though, the minor issue of cost aside, vry well done, and I hope to see more like this again.

21080904.review: To my suprise a very immersive game :-) I usually stick to big title fps/rpgs. The artwork, music and characters are all great. And the story/choices you have keeps you focused/interested. Try something different and get this game!! :-)

I found this game surprisingly enjoyable.  While a lot compare this game to Phoenix Wright, I think the similarity ends with it being a lawyer game (there need to be more of these) where you interview people.  
I really loved the aspect of your choices making a difference as well.  In other lawyer games your choices usually end in a pass/fail state.  While this game your choices can cause different outcomes.  I like that.  
The story was also beautiful.  I loved the characters I loved how they all had unique personas, even considering they were animals, I think it was brilliant.
The graphics while simple, were also beautiful.  Personally I like this art style of sketch looking figures and a not over the top animation style.  It was simple but elegant.  
Because the game offers different endings, it does allow for some replayability

Aviary Attorney takes the Ace Attorney formula and runs with it. Multiple endings, side quests, as well as the ability to lose and keep playing. For more info, check out my review:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fgwtz6Xph_Q

21052490.review:
This may seem like just another Phoenix Wright clone, but it is so much more. This game definitely pays homage to the Ace Attorney series, but it stands on its on two feet. The game is witty, amusing and generally gets you invested in the characters. The replay value of this game is big positive for me. The fact that you can start trail completely unprepared is not a bad thing.
1. It's realistic that you can't have all the time in the world to comb all of Paris for clues before a trail date. So sometimes you miss some, so what? Live with it.
2. It allows you to learn from your mistakes and replay the scenes if you want to or just continue the story.
3. It allows for different outcomes throughout the game. 

This game doesn't just stop and say, "Sorry you lost, try again?" It continues the story and lets you live with your mistakes. Too few games do that. I HIGHLY recommend this game to people who love the Ace Attorney games and to anyone who just likes a good story laced with humor and bad (good) puns.

21046324.review: Yes, it's a Phoenix Wright clone, and no, it doesn't really make any improvements to the basic formula. But it does defy certain expectations, such that the story actually goes somewhere. The writing isn't incisive enough to actually get it there, but the fact that it addresses real issues puts it in about the 90th percentile, as far as these things go.

21035371.review:
A wonderful variant on the tried-and-true Ace Attorney style.

Unlike the AA games, Aviary Attorney has a much stronger emphasis on the investigation part of the game, while the court sections are rather brief, but both are handled well. There's a push for greater realism in the court part of the game: while you can do the whole Phoenix Wright thing and find the real criminal and force him to confess in court, it's not always a requirement for a not guilty verdict. Simply demonstrating reasonable doubt IS sufficient.

It's also notable that the investigation sections have an action limit: going to a location to investigate it takes a day, and wasting time can mean the difference between mere acquittal and catching the real culprit -- or even outright failure -- since the trials are on fixed days that can't be moved.

But failure actually isn't the end in Aviary Attorney. The game has multiple possible endings, and failing cases can be necessary for some. In this way, the way you play the game determines not only the outcome, but also the tone of the game itself: idealistic play will result in an idealistic game, cynical play will result in a cynical game, and wacky Ace Attorney play can result in a wacky Ace Attorney game.

I laughed, I cried, I got punched by a lion. 9/10, could use meatier trial sections but great game nonetheless.

21012074.review: The art style was  enough to peak my interest in this game but what hooked me was the world and stort this game had to tell. Aviary Attorney is a game that made me step back at the end just agast with amazement and the feelings that only a good story makes you feel. This game is truly a work of art and I recommend it wholely. I will say coming to this game knowing as little as possible is highly recommended and will greatly improve your experience.

20917753.review: I found this game disappointing.  A court game lives or dies on its dialogue, and this dialogue is either boring or downright bad.   To add color, one of the suspects speaks in fake-Cockney, sprinkled with words like " 'ave" and "sayin' ".   However, he also says okie-dokie, a glaringly American term.   Although the drawings, the music, and the names are French, and the game is set in Paris, there's no French flavor at all to the dialogue, no French epithets or turns of phrase.  The two investigators you're guiding aren't well characterized -- the sidekick makes bad, not funny-bad, just bad, puns, and the lead investigator is solemn and rebukes the sidekick.   Finally, evidence searches are literal pixel-hunting: when the background is a cross-hatched engraving with lots of detail, it's almost impossible to guess which object is unusual and which is part of the original drawing.   I wound up sweeping my mouse across every part of the page to try to find objects.

20873575.review:
LD;DR: If you like Ace Attorney, GO FOR IT, NO SECOND THOUGHTS. 

Now for a slightly more, say, eloquent review:

First of all, in order to set my bias status: I am not a Kickstarter backer, and a fan of the Phoenix Wright series. Mind that I do rarely wright reviews (pun intended) and I really really want to see a sequel of this game. 

That said, this game exceeded my expectations in many, many ways. I was at first quite happy to buy an Ace Attorney clone and to my uttermost surprise right on the second case this game seemed like it would fit on the "pupil surpasses master" category. I was correct.

Why should you buy it:

It's not only really well written and crafted, It feels way more dangerous than Ace Attorney. You see, the trials have dates, and you better get the job done of asking the right questions and collecting the correct evidence before the trial day otherwhise [b]you will go to court without the necessary assets to win the case [/b]. If you do a poor job at investigation phase, you will fail...
...and that's the best part. Failing doesn't mean you will get a "game over" screen. There is a special case that might go in threee different paths depending on your performance and decisions. 

It's a delightful twist to the Ace series, while it doesn't have a Bioware/Telltale range of storyline paths, it doesen't feels like you're been railed visual-novel style. The text is clever, the smart and non-lazy use of Creative Commons art works marvelously, the plot twists are quite twisty indeed and if you think this game is full of puns, well, you're wright (strike two). 
You'll more than once think "well, that escalated quickly".

And to end the "why should you buy this" rant: it's amazing how a pun-riddled game about antropomorphic animals performing mundane tasks can be quite a banquet for though.

And don't worry about the  [b]CONS[/b], for they're few :
- A little glitchy here and there, I particularly had a lot of trouble with sound and had to lower my sound config in order to have it working properly.
- The interface is quite pretty looking but messy and non-intuitive sometimes. Examples: 1: there is a blackjack mini-game that would benefit a lot from a "Replay" button without the need to go through dialogue again in order to play it. 2 : The main map of the game is quite messy, sometimes it tries to prompt you with a special cinematic and the prompt has exactly the same color of the background so is quite easy to miss. Besides, it does not tell you the day the trial will occur, nor allows you to check your evidence and suspects folder.


Buy this game wright now and you wont regret it (strike 3. Im out).

20865240.review:
A Phoenix Wright-ish VN you can finish in about 4-5 hours.  A bit of variety in the endings, but what makes it stand out is its characters.  Despite all being ridiculously animal-headed gentlemen, all of them are interesting and enjoyable in their own way, like Sparrowson's quick wit with both puns and investigation, and Prince Juan's over-the-top flamboyance(Hell, he's friggn reading DON QUIXOTE when you first meet him.)  

There's not that much to the gameplay, mostly just choosing the right lines to cross-examine and well-utilizing the limited days you have, and the latter can be pretty frustrating when going certain places, even when they waste your time, can take a whole day away.  

But even with all that, It has a really well-written narrative that really manages to keep you on edge, and does a good job to create the feeling of 19th century french revolution.  As ridiculous as that sounds.  Oh, and you'll get a mormon joke at the end, so mostly worth it.  8/10   Not top notch, but worth a playthrough.

20864552.review:
A must for [i]Ace Attorney[/i] fans and ornithology enthusiasts alike!

An excellent game, but short and fairly simple.

There are only 3 missions and 1 ending mission (with three possible endings based on the prior mission). Each mission is pretty solid all in all, with some pretty funny characters and a decent amount of thought required to go into the cases. My only regret is that it ends so early and that the cases are usually relatively straightforward, if there were a few more red herrings and complications/suspects in the cases I think this game would be absolutely top notch. The art style and setting are unique and done well and the whole interface is straightforward.

Saying that, i'd still recommend it for a quick bit of a fun. Personally I was happy with the ending I got so I felt no need to go looking for the other two, but I did mess around a bit so I think my playtime is round about what you would need to finish the game.

I really wanted to like this game, and it has its moments, but overall, the entire package just falls flat. The dialog is well written, but the story tends to thrash about, never fully developing plot points. The courtroom sections are absolutely awful. Not a single case reached the excitement of even the first case of any Phoenix Wright game. There are no twists, no challenges, and there isn't really anything to figure out. It just kind of... continues on... There are only 2 real cases in the game (The intro was far too short and simple to count), and surprisingly, the final case is by far the worst, most shallow and uninteresting mess ever. I can't even call it a case. You're literally lying the entire time and there is no outcome to the trial.

It's not that I was unhappy while playing this, but there were just way too many "Wow, really? That's it?" moments for me to recommend anyone pay more than $5 for this.

20818513.review:
This was a really great game. Scratched that Phoenix Wright itch just enough, and did some things very differently than it too. One thing that's interesting, is you can start a case fully unprepared if you so choose.

I enjoyed the art style, and really dug the music (I got the soundtrack from steam). Dialogue was very nice, and the choices never felt like they went in a way I didn't expect. I was never really puzzled with the cases, but I was always wondering if I got everything I possibly could on the trial days (no walkthroughs used). I also want to say that there's some genuinely funny moments that made me laugh hard; but it doesn't ever feel too forced.

The story was good, maybe a little short (it's one of the few games I've finished in a while, so I feel good about that). But, there's mutliple endings, and after completion it gives you and idea of how to unlock the others, which is nice. (No need to go through the full story and find out a lot of stuff doesn't affect the outcome).

Overall, I really enjoyed the game. I feel like it lived up to its $15 price tag, but that might not be the case for everyone. If it piques your interst but can't justify the price, I'd highly recommend putting this on your "steam sale" list.

20756064.review:
I wanted to love this game, I really did, but by the end of it (or shall I say the end of one path) I utterly hated it.

The game is surely pretty and quite funny at times, so much so that you'd like to explore more of it and its world, except for the fact that [b]you can't[/b] and [b]you shouldn't[/b]. You see, most of the cases rely on a clock, that ticks after each place you visit. Either you do things as fast as you can, in a correct manner, skipping very interesting places in the process, or you're stuck and out of luck. Eventually you'll come across a case that requires a piece of evidence that the game didn't let you grab, and instead of just going for the "we have nothing to show for it" à la Ace Attorney, you can only fail intentionally 3 times because the frickin' inventory screen won't go away, further aggravating your rage.

Important/interesting key objects that get in your inventory and that might be used in later stages, actually don't get used at all and are simply discarded, with characters pretending to have never seen such a thing.

To top it off, there is no "quick skip" dialogue if you want to just mow over dialogues you already read several times and stopping it on "new dialogues" only.

Hell, there isn't even a way to save right where you are. I mistakenly took the "Save & Quit" option in the menu as actually save and quit, only to find out that [i]upon reload all the dialogues were reset[/i], and basically I had to redo most of the stuff I went through, because [b]there are no in-between save states[/b].

So, to sum it all up:
[list][*] you can't properly save and load if your life depended on it;
[*] you can't explore because you're on a clock;
[*] you cannot skip dialogues that you have to mandatorily read multiple times if you want to experience all the endings;
[*] since clock often ticks when you visit a place, if you want to actually go back to some place you already visited, the additional visit also takes time off the clock… god forbid you willingly go to a place where it turns out there was nothing helpful…[/list]

No, this game has failed me completely, ruining the experiences I like the most in games of this genre. The fact they made it possible for players to be hindered by their will to explore more of the game, is an unforgivable sin.

20674316.review:
Comparisons to Ace Attorney are inevitible, as they're intentionally self-evoked here, but Aviary Attorney does have more than enough to it that makes it a much different experience.

For one, the game is more about breadth than depth. The main storyline only took me around 4 hours to complete, but my playtime double going through the game again to see alternate paths and the other two endings. Each trial has multiple outcomes that can affect the story in different ways ranging from a few small details to three distinct endings. The game has a lot more replayability to it than the linear Ace Attorney games, and that's not a knock against Ace Attorney either, the linearity allows the game to provide a much more in-depth story.

That's not to say the story in Aviary Attorney is lacking; far from it. What starts off as a silly bird-lawyering game escalates into a turbulent tale of rebellion and violence, with three potential outcomes. The game is far darker than Ace Attorney ever gets, and the scope of your actions is far more reaching than the relatively minimal stakes the Ace Attorney series sticks to. There's a variety of characters with interesting personality quirks and a good dose of humor as well, the game can still be fairly lighthearted at times, but going in expecting something as over-the-top silly as Ace Attorney would be a mistake.

The gameplay also differs a fair bit. For one, it's much more fast-paced. Investigations are done a day at a time, and you have a limited time to get everything done that you need done, making it possible to fail any trial if you don't have proper evidence (or simply present the wrong evidence too many times). The first case is fairly trivial to complete, but it's possible to miss some crucial details in the second case and the third case is actually quite strict as far as what you need to do to ensure a successful trial, while giving you more options than you'll know what to do with. There's a bit of a trial-and-error element but when you have a sense of what you're missing or what you did wrong, it's not too hard to put the pieces together and have a perfect case after only a replay or two. And replays can be done fairly quick as the text is all fast to skip.

If I were to have any real problems with the game, it would mostly come down to three issues. First, path 4A is a bit... awful, storywise. It forces one of the main characters way out of character to push an overly dramatic and hard to take seriously storyline, though since the player intentionally has to initiate this ending, perhaps it was done on purpose? Either way, I wouldn't consider this ending "canon", and it's only one of three. 

The second issue is that there are a fair few instances of script breaking, where the game will have assumed an event took place even if it didn't. This tends to only occur if you intentionally try to screw up things though, and the only major script break I encountered was a result of intentionally failing the first case early, though there are certainly others to be found.

The third issue, and this is only a minor nitpick, is the price vs. length issue. 8 hours is what it took for me to experience the vast majority of what this game has to offer (some branching dialogue paths and two failure states I didn't achieve that wouldn't change much in the long run) and while it's not impossible that I'll revisit it in the future, it still feels either a tad short for the price or a tad overpriced for the length. 

But I digress, anyways. It's a very well-made game with a great story, a unique and interesting art style, and there are bird puns. I quite enjoyed my experience with this game, in spite of the small issues I have with it. Definitely recommended.

- 6/10 - не для всех! :-\ 

- что касается механики игры в жанре "симулятор адвоката" - все очень стандартно, грустно и печально (даже если вы просто где-то краем уха слышали о существовании серии игр "Ace Attorney", например) - преступление > поиск улик > перекрестный допрос - без особых изысков, ничего примечательного ... все что касается проработки персонажей и диалогов - исполнено на уровне всего лишь качественного клише, неожиданных влюбленностей в характеры и судьбы не замечено ... и тут - БАЦ! - изумительный антураж из кусочков политической карикатуры Жана Гранвиля (известного в пределах "русской Википедии" в роли "ближайшего предшественника сюрреализма") с хрустящими кусочками Франции времен революции 1848 года - ну, то-есть, все роли в данной постановке исполняют животные - хо-хо, вы все понимаете! - отличная находка, ощущается свежо и волнующе, временами второпях и не по делу, но очень искренне - тем самым добавляя несколько граней к никогда не теряющей актуальности теме преступления и наказания, и неправосудного наказания, и независимого суда, и права на справедливое судебное разбирательство, и верховенство закона, и одинаковости его для всех, и справедливости ради справедливости ... туше, мон ами! :]

A game about law and justice set in 1840s Paris. The country has received ceveral political turnovers in the recent decades, made a swing from republic back into the Ancient Regime and is currently in the final stages of Louis Philippe's reign.

The system in Paris is corrupted as we know and love it, filled with strong characters prone to dramatic acts and speeches.
The humour I found particularly good. The whole theme of justice as a moral feeling and a social necessity is played out very well. The only negative point I could think of is that it is not particularly hard to figure things out.

20571842.review:
HUN: Nagyszerű játék. Tényleg nagyszerű. Tökéletes történetvezetés, szuper dialógusok és lebilincselő karakterek. Angol és Francia fekete humor keveredik elég komoly társadalomkritikával... de hagyjuk a rizsát, a lényeg, hogy élvezet volt végigjátszani, minden egyes mondata a helyén van, az ügyek ötletesek, a történet pedig meglepő és fordulatos. Egyedül talán az utolsó részt éreztem egy kicsit gyengének a többihez képest, valamint a lezárás nem volt eléggé katarktikus... DE  valójában csak azért vagyok szomorú, mert vége lett. 7 óra alatt játszottam végig elsőre, ami nem rossz, de ilyen minőségi játék esetében legalább még egyszer ennyit szerettem volna. Várom a második részt J.J és Sparrowson visszatérésével, vagy akár Renard és Mousey főszereplésével! 

-------------------------

ENG: Great game. Really great. Perfect storyline, engaging characters and superb dialogues. English and French "black  and absurd" humor mixed with serious social criticism ...  But the real deal is: 
It was fun to play through, each sentence is in place, the story is surprising and eventful. 
Only the last part felt a little weak compared to the others, and the closure was not sufficiently cathartic ... but actually I'm just sad because it was over. 
I played through the first time in 7 hours, which is not bad, but for such a quality of a game, that much I would have liked at least one more time. 
I am looking forward to the second part with the return of J.J and Sparrowson, or even starring Renard and Mousey!

I've played through all the endings and never encountered any bugs - they're don't seem to be quite as prevalent as some of the comments make them out to be. The price to gametime ratio is about the same as Ace Attorney games.

Overall, a very charming game with witty dialogue, cute throwbacks to Ace Attorney, a pretty satisfying choice system, and some surprisingly dark themes. I was more satisfied with the way this game handled "mature" themes, like the grey side of the law, than even in AA: Dual Destinies. The music is also spot on and really transports you to the game's era. 

Also, birds. You get to be a BIRD LAWYER. Birds.

20547571.review:
This is a great game for fans of the Ace Attorney series. It definitely will help fill the gap until AA6. The character design and art style are fantastic, though there isn't much animation on the characters like in the Ace Attorney games. It's also on the short side compared to the Ace Attorney games, and the cases are somewhat simpler. 

The endings are pretty interesting, with one in particular going in a direction I never would've expected, and they make up a good portion of the gameplay- they aren't just cutscenes at the end. 

I enjoyed the characters, though the similarities between Falcon/Severin and Wright/Edgeworth are pretty hard to miss.

Overall, I'd recommend it.

As a Phoenix Wright fan I was looking for something similar to kill time, I didn't expect much from what seemed like a simple spin off. Despite being in the 1800's era, the dialogue still manages to be relatable & hilarious.  It's not an exceptionally long game but that doesn't make it bad. If you enjoy the type of banter that occurs during the PW games, this title is a great addition that can proudly stand on its own.

20534303.review:
No Objection sounds
0/10.

But in all seriousness.
Being a fan of the Ace Attorney games this pays a rather decent Hommage to the series. *I noticed that "Ladder - Stepladder" argument from Nick and Maya in there*
I will get a bit nitpicky about things here though.
During investigations I find it hard to tell if I'm missing anything or not until I click away from the investigation screen, Using the most recent Ace Attorney game (Dual Destinies) as a point of reference, when you have finished looking around and found everything it automatically closes you out of the investigation mode.

I found myself getting through investigations rather quickly, making it a rather shortlived overworld experience.

The music while I do agree fits the theme of the game, I found it didn't change enough, especially in the courtroom.

Getting SUPER nitpicky here, I still would've loved to hear a bird say OBJECTION! but then again I guess that would've made it a bit TOO similar to the Ace Attorney games, and you probably would've run into some legal trouble and Blah Blah Blah.

So for relatively new players to Crime investigation games, I suggest picking up the Ace Attorney series as those games have similar gameplay mechanics, and they are a lot of fun to play.
And then pick up this game once you have gotten through a few of those games.

But for people who already enjoy the Ace Attorney series go ahead and pick this game up, its a lot of fun to play in your downtime.

20534220.review:
I was expecting a decent attempt at an Ace Attorney game with an odd art style and got so much more! I've played all the Ace Attorney games, spin-offs, and mash-ups... enjoyed them through their highs and lows, but Aviary Attorney still finds some new ambitious new ground to cover and succeeds. The scope seems a little smaller (maybe the size of a long Phoenix Wright turnabout), but it also feels more like detective work and more like a court room drama. I've only seen one of the 4 endings (what I can only assume is the bad ending) and it's nice to see my poor performance result in a dramatic poor outcome rather than forcing me to reload the chapter.

The writing is top notch: funny characters, clever dialog, and interesting twists. The art is a bizarre choice, but immediately won me over. I wish there was a little more animation, but the audio and effects do a good job of making up for this. I'm excited to try the other endings and for more from these devs.

20490337.review:
Aviary Attorney was one of the standout games of my alcohol fuelled Steam sale binge. You take on the role of JayJay Falcon, Paris' finest bird defence lawyer as he investigates crimes, interviews witnesses, assembles cases and proves his clients innocence. Fans of the Ace Attorney games will be right at home with the gameplay, but be warned if you fail a case you carry on regardless, albeit in a more morose mood than before. Time waits for no man, and neither does Aviary Attorney, if you failed to pick up the crucial piece of evidence then you will be punished for it later. The story changes depending on your actions, a refreshing change from chronically linear games that inspired it.


The aesthetics of the game are a lovingly curated experience, the character art is from J.J. Grandville’s “The Public and Private Life of Animals”, the backgrounds and objects are from other period books, and even the font is old! The attention to detail is staggering, not a single piece looks out of place. Combine this with a lovely soundtrack comprised of music by romantic-era composer Camille Saint-Saëns and you have a gorgeous game straight out of 1840’s Paris.


Hilarious to a fault when it wants to be and surprisingly dark when it needs to, you are playing a tense, pre-revolution Paris after all. If you need more courtroom style games in your life, this is certainly a good place to start.

20487762.review:

20484003.review:
Excellent game overall. Fantastic visual and audio presentation and very good writing striking a good balance of the dramatic and comedic. My only complaint is the exploration feels a bit rigid at times, not allowing you to push your luck as much in conversation choices as similar games, to explore every interaction. At worst it can require you to essentially fail some of the later acts on the first try without prior knowedge of the correct lead and therefore meeting the schedule of the case. It makes up for this somewhat it making it very easy to travel back to any day of the act you choose without a lot of manual savepoint nonsense, but for me this somewhat degrades the intensity of the aha moments or to make correct choices as the cost for the benefit of allowing you a lot of freedom of changing the course of investagations.
Overall, if one is a fan of adventure games, other mystery/investagative/attoney games, or visual novels, I think this would be an enjoyable fit.

20482671.review: I loved it! I've played through the Ace Attorney series about three or four times, and Aviary Attorney is just as fun, maybe more so in some ways. It's not just a rip-off, though. I liked how it's possible to miss evidence and fail trials, and wind up with different endings. It adds more realism and replay value, compared to Ace Attorney where you're forced to follow the correct path or it's game over. It was also refreshing that it included the ability to find someone "not guilty" without necessarily having to prove that someone else did it. Which is the way the law actually works, at least that I'm aware of. The art and music are beautiful. I love the way the characters are animated, and the huge variety of animals involved. Also: stepladder jokes.

20479307.review: I had such a great time with this game--the art is lovely, the music is great, and the character writing is fantastic. It has a decidedly different feel from Phoenix Wright; it's both darker and sweeter, in some ways. There's a bit more pressure on the logic of investigation than in other attorney games I've played, which makes gameplay feel a bit different, too. Although it's a short game, it's definitely worth the money, and I look forward to more games from this team!

20446656.review:
For all it's worth Aviary Attorney is an incredibly well put together twist on the Ace Attorney formular. The cases and characters are a lot of fun and it's really refreshing that you're not just strictly following a point & click hallway as is the case with Phoenix Wright and Apollo Justice, but that you're decisions, actions and your cleverness influence the story and the endings in different ways. By no means does it invent the wheel in a new way, but it's refreshing nonetheless.

If there's one flaw, then that at the end you're probably gonna be craving more. The puzzles and trials are not incredibly complex or difficult, especially if you're familiar with the Ace Attorney games, so there's a big chance that you'll find the game lacking a bit on the challenge departement.

20435975.review:
TL:DR, : Similar to the other "AA". Contains humor, mood whiplash, investigations, quirky characters and plenty of punny moments.

Non TL;DR: This game is quite similar to another game involving a blue suited attorney and a klepto of an assistant, but requires a little more investigation skills as investigations are not set in stone. If you go the wrong way, you will not get everything you need to reveal the truth.

No matter which way you go, you will still find plenty of shenanigans.

Gameplay consists largely of pointing and clicking. Questioning people is not as simple as pressing everything, because if you say the wrong thing, you'll offend the person you're questioning and lose the ability to talk to that person. 

There is also a wallet you have to keep track of, as you'll need to buy things over the course of your investigating and lawyering. (You do get paid, too.)

Bottom line: Recommended.

20435748.review:
I'm a huge Ace Attorney fan, and as such, I got disappointed pretty often by games that "tried" or were "supposed to be" similar to my favorite game series. Because what makes it unique isn't the fact that it is a mystery visual novel, but the lovably-strange characters, the dialogues that are so cheesy for most of the time you just have to laugh about them, the remarkable soundtracks, and also the few adventure elements do their share. And Aviary Attorney is probably the closest, and in my opinion best thing to the original games I've played so far.

Why? Because it doesn't even try to hide its source of inspiration (I mean, just reading the game title indicates that much.), it is an almost shameless copy of Ace Attorney in every aspect I mentioned above, and it's doing this just great. I've really had a lot of fun with these four cases and have no complaints about their quality, although especially the first two are quite short.

So, if you're an Ace Attorney fan: Buy this game, you will most certainly love it like I did.
If you're not into Ace Attorney or even visual novels: Give it a try anyway, it might be a great possibility for you to get into both of these things (I'm not that much of a VN fan myself). But, one way or another, Aviary Attorney definitely deserves more attention. 

And if you'll excuse me now, I think I'll be going back to waiting for Ace Attorney 6.

The twists and turns in the cases will have you groaning at the antics of the character (particularly Sparrowson). Examine all of the evidence, and do it quickly. Time is of the essence.

This game is definately one that will be replayed- I want to see all of the witty dialogue that was presented.  10/10 worth every penny.

20393339.review:
It's a good game, however, as it is heavily inspired by the Ace Attorney series, you can't help but compare them. Unfortunately, Aviary doesn't hold well against Ace. The story is simpler and shorter, the cases are less complicated and also too short. The characters are way less interesting. The visuals are really good, but the lack of colours gets boring fast.
Aviary also has generally less gameplay which, together with scarce animation, gives it more of a visual novel feel to it.
There are also some technical difficulties, like the custom cursor disappearing when it leaves the window or the fact that the "save and quit" option does only the latter. It's worth noting that the game was really finished a few days ago, despite the fact it hadn't been released in an early access form.

All in all, Aviary Attorney is a good game for people who either played Ace Attorney games and want more, or just can't play them because they don't own the handhelds they were released for.

20381221.review:
Time to write a review... FOR JUSTICE!

The facts are these:
#1: The writing is charming, witty, and quite punny (and there are a few jokes for those who speak French)
#2: The art style is boldly different, yet somehow nothing is lacking in the visuals. The details are beautiful and every new character/animal has a completely fresh design that is great to see.
#3: The story itself is extremely interesting. Each case warms you up to the over-arching narrative that takes some detective-work on the player's part to piece together. Will all these facts collide in the developing Chapter 5? I hope so.
#4: While hilarious, the story also takes itself quite seriously. One wrong move on the player's part could result in a death, not just a "game over." In this spirit, the story is grounded in the very real setting of revolutionary France, allowing the history buffs a bit of a spree through tumultous times.
#5: The so-called "negative" reviews of this game are actually worth a read, because most praise the game in the highest fashion. Some bird-brains just can't wait 5 days for one of 3 intricate endings to be polished and delivered. A miscommunication, at best. Having played all three endings (the delayed ending cannonically last, in my case), I would say it was well worth the short wait.

The Verdict:
GUILTY of being a wonderful romp through mystery, art, wit, and great characters. This game is worth a play (or three), and I take off my hat to the developers. I, for one, am happily looking forward to the promise of even more in the future. Due process and all that.

Review ADJOURNED.

20379783.review: Despite the premise, this game is less an Ace Attorney-clone and more of its own beast. So whether you'll like this game or not depends on your expactations: if you want to scratch that Ace Attorney-itch, this game might disappoint you. There are 4 cases in total, but only half of them follow the Ace Attorney-formula; the other half "plays" a lot more like graphic novels with easy puzzles/cross-examinations. However, if you are looking for an unique graphic novel with fantastic writing, go for it - these strong points make me recommend this game.

20369618.review:
Though I do recommend this game, I feel like some of you might be surprised by the actual amount of content in the game. 

There are 4 cases in this game with Case 4 having 3 different parts depending on the results of Case 3. Though this seems like a lot of content, I was able to go through the game in approximately 8 hours at a leisurely pace. I have no doubts someone could get through this game in 5 or less hours. 

I will say this game has great music, art, and dialogue. You can definitely feel the love and effort that was given to these areas of the game and I loved it. It truly felt refreshing. 

The story however is short and, in my opinion, a little lacking. All of the cases are quick and have rather simple scenerios. Especially Case 4, where investigation is streamlined and we are given short and simple endings. Case 3 probably took the longest but only because you have to go through it fully twice to get both the endings. 

Now, at it's modest price tag of 15$ (compared to Ace Attorney's 35$ on release) you get a comperable amount of time for your dollar. However, don't be expecting long/intricate cases or a thrilling plot. But do prepare to chuckle whenever Sparrowson speaks.

20345989.review:
Sort of a graphic novel with music by Saint-Saens and art by J.J. Grandville set around the French Revolution.
Most of the game is decided by how you spent the days leading up to the trial and if you have the evidence required to poke holes in witness testimoy. There's really not much else to it but that.
That said, the dialogue reminded me a bit of Sam & Max. All of the interactions put a smile on my face. I found all the characters interesting.

Only real problem I had with the game was a bug with the music and sound coming through my speakers staticy sometimes. Couldn't find a fix for that on the steam forums.

20344954.review:
With the new update bringing ending 4-C, I can finally recommend this game with good conscience. Not that the game wasn't good before, but it was imcomplete prior to the update, which is worth mentioning.

Anyway, with that out of the way, Aviary Attorney is a fantastic game with great art and writing. Characters have interesting anthropromorphic animal designs, the characters are likeable and memorable, and the dialogue is clever. Fans of the Ace Attorney series will definitely find a lot of similarities from that series in this game, but there are enough differences and new twists to make this game worth it. For example, there are branching paths (you can get three major endings in fact), and it is possible to fail cases and continue the game with your failure affecting various portions. Investigation segments are also a lot of fun due to having to choose carefully on where you choose to investigate. If you make poor choices, you might not get all the info and evidence necessary to save your client.

Overall, I highly recommend this game, especially to fans of the Ace Attorney series.

My only complaint is the lack of sound effects for guns. The screen just sorta goes black, and it's a little weird.

But it will probably be back in fairly soon and you don't have to pay for it, so I don't really see the issue. Also, you only get the particular version of the chapter if you fuck up the previous one. So, uh, don't do that, I guess. 

Speaking of elephants in rooms, you may have noticed that all of the characters are animals. The art style is actually one of the game's strongest points. And I don't say that often. The fact that they're animals is hardly important to the plot, beyond a few puns and maybe cats clawing people to death. It's a neat way of having all the characters be visually distinct without resorting to shitty anime drawings. And despite the game being a visual novel, there are quite a few charming little animations to give things a bit more character.

The gameplay is pretty inventive, but sadly underutilised. It's like Ace Attorney, unsurprisingly. There's an investigation phase, where you talk to witnesses and look for clues, and then the trial phase, where you present evidence to contradict the witness' testimony. It's all very talky. The key difference with Aviary Attorney is the time limit during the investigation phase. Each place you investigate will take you a full day, and you have only a limited time before the trial starts. If you faff about going to the same locations too many times, or in the wrong order, you might not have all the clues ready for the trial. Which means you might not get the best possible ending.

This is something a lot of mystery games lack- an actual failure state. Too many allow you to click on everything until you find the solution. It's neat that the game doesn't patronise me by making the solution too obvious. 

It's not all perfect though. I found the game to be pretty easy- I got the best ending for every case on my first try. I mean, it probably helps that I've played Ace Attorney and Danganronpa before, but even if you haven't, the game heavily hints at where to go next during the investigation phase, and the trial phase usually has fairly obvious contradictions. If you don't know what to do during the trial, just press every statement. Eventually, someone will say something like "I bet you can't prove that the witness owns a massive blood stained knife", at which point you present a bloody knife with their name signed on the handle. 

The trials are also very short. There's only really two full trials to sink your teeth into. The first case is more of a tutorial and the fourth is just an excuse for some story. Not even particularly good story, the variant I ended up with (the one you get for succeeding in Act 3) was all about protecting a character the player doesn't care about. I can't really blame the developers, it's enough for the price tag, but I guess Ace Attorney has spoiled me into wanting more.

Besides the last act the writing is actually pretty excellent. It's funny, and not just "funny by video game humour standards". Legitimately funny. It also completely avoids the common mistake VNs make of describing a thing we can already see because it's a VISUAL novel.

In short:

Pros:
+Excellent writing
+Unique art styles
+Interesting investigations and trials
+Likeable characters

Negatives:
-A little on the short side
-Too easy
-A few mild bugs
-No log to reread dialogue that you might have missed
-Slightly incomplete

In short, it's a unique game that's worth experiencing despite its flaws. I hope the developers can explore some of these ideas more fully in a sequel.

20327722.review:
Take a journey through the fowl world of late 1840's France on the verge of another revolution as legal eagle attorney extraordinaire JayJay Falcon a hard drinking but dedicated defense attorney, accompanied by his faithful chirpy comic relief sidekick Sparrowson in Aviary Attorney. Can you get your clients off the hook or will they find their goose is cooked? Bird puns out of my system let's get down to it!

Gameplay is greatly inspired by the Phoenix Wright series. Anyone experienced in those games will easily understand how this game works. You'll wade through sticky tangled webs of court room drama. Scour the cobblestone streets and back alleys of Paris for clues, make decisions on whether or not to use less than legal methods to obtain evidence, examine witness testimony, use logic and deduction in order to put all the pieces together to present your case. All the while coming to discover serving "justice" can be a messy complex affair.

The first thing to probably hit you is the astounding whimiscal caricature artwork that's highlighted throughout the game. Along with the backgrounds that range from smoke ridden taverns, to that of genuine historic sites and palaces of 19th century Paris. The anthropomorphic characters make up wonderfully strange an beautiful imagery. The artistic style of Jean-Jacques Grandville very much stands out for it's ability to conjure up such fantastic characters. The background surroundings you find yourself in are mainly borrowed from old illustrations that you would find in ads, catalogs and publications of the time. Pairing these two together and piecing them into a story results in a remarkable great looking game.

Music consists of many wonderfully orchestrated classical scores. Including the very fitting and recognizable "Funeral March Of A Marionette" that many would recall from it's use in the Alfred Hitchcock television show. Everything sound wise fits in with the period and serves to enhance the dramatic tense undergoings of the court room. 

Writing and plot can make or break this type of game. Luckily the story is full of some great moments. Especially as you delve deeper into each case. The story likes to leave you with certain doubts by unfolding the dastardly truth along with the glaring cracks that make up our imperfect sense of justice. It leaves you with some thought provoking feelings as you consider the different possiblities and motives of each case you're assigned. The writer seems to make good choices as to when to inject humor and when to take itself more seriously. It keeps the over all atmosphere and tone to each scene consistant and immersive. Resisting falling into the trap of trying to hard to slap you in face with jokes, which can be tempting to do in this type of game. Nor does it always take itself to seriously and knows when to use timing to deliver a good joke.

All in all it's a very interesting game that any lover of adventures, visual novels, and of course Ace Attorney games will appreciate. I would personally rate Aviary Attorney overall as a 9 out of 10. Highly recommended good fun that draws you in and makes it hard to put down.

20309216.review:
While this game currently has more than it's fair share of bugs, it is still a nice game. While the bugs are indeed plenty, they are rather minor. It is indeed true that one of the endings is flat out missing, but the endings are a rather small part of the game.

The art in the game is excellent. It is well implemented and characters are interesting. Veterans of Ace Attorney may find the few poses for each character a little disappointing, but it never feels as if the game could have used any specific additional pose. The backgrounds are quite excellent as well.

The music is quite nice and the voice bleeps are fitting and actually an improvement over the typical Ace Attorney ones, if only because of their larger variation and style.

The game is rather short. But so is the story. The length of the game matches the story well and it never feels as if the pacing is too slow or too fast. The price is however a bit too much for the length of the game.

The story is generally well written, even if short. However, the integration with the gameplay falters at times. The good ending is a bit of a meh deal, especially with the rather lacking investigation and trivial trial. It is a bit of a let down compared to the rest of the game. But aside from the ending, it is quite interesting. There is a good underlying story going on beneath the cases you take on and it is just right in intensity, you know it's there, but it's not screaming at you.

The main problem with the gameplay is the ability to bumble the investigation, ruining your chances at the trial. This game makes it obvious why the Ace Attorney games don't let you do that. It's not just "oh dear, i am failing this trial", but you also risk missing major parts of the story simply by never getting that far in the investigations.

The game has had a rather rough release, with poor testing and an obvious Christmas rush. Time will save the game, even if the developer has repeatedly proven themself unable to obey their own deadlines.

Overall, do play this game. But you might want to wait for another sale and the game being finished.

20308303.review:
I am writing this review to confront some concerns with the developer. By the way, when I say "some people" I have read comments from Steam reviews, reddit and other forums. Just so you know I'm not strawman-ing.

First of all, I have very few qualms with the game. If you enjoyed Phoenix Wright, you will likely enjoy this. I especially love that there are multiple ways to end cases! The only things I do not like is the lack of fast text skipping (like the way you would hold shift to quickly skip through text in a visual novel) and how short the cases are. There are also some problems with sound balance, but it's not a big deal. On the merits of the game alone, I would happily reccommend this game.

Now I'd like to write a little in the developer's defense: I was not part of the Kickstarter, so I cannot tell you how they communicated during that, however I think the current controversy is overblown. The first complaint I have heard is to do with bugs: as far as I know, the developers of this game have not made a game before. If you have made a game before, you would know that bug testing is an odd process. Often a developer simple cannot encounter the same bugs that a player will. They need a second set of eyes. To combat this, the devs should have released a build to their backers to test before release. I first played the game post patch and I have not encountered any bugs at all. I don't want to call anyone a liar, but the game isn't riddle with glitches at all. From the reviews around here you'd think is it, but I digress.

The second complaint I have seen is that the game was released unfinished. This is unacceptable. It is! However, with a little digging around, I found that the devs were way, way, way over budget and deadline. I understand why they would release it early. The big problem here is that they didn't initially say it was missing the last part. They have since changed this on the steam page. However, I do agree they should have been unfront about this in the first place. 

I have heard people say that they should have released it as early access, if they couldn't delay it. The devs said they were going to add the last part in a few days after release, so it would have been silly to stay in EA for such a short time. Unfortunately, this didn't turn out the way intended: we still do not have the final part as of the 4th of January. I'm giving the devs the benefit of the doubt and say that they didn't intend for this to happen. We already know that they were over-budget and past their hard deadline, so it's clear that this project has gone out of control. This really sucks for everyone, but the devs seem to be trying to make the best out of it. If they release it soon, I think they deserve some kind of forgiveness.

I want to put my reason for defending these devs into perspective: they are first time devs. They do not know how this all works. The way I've seen people lamblasting them, you'd think this was all a big con. I've been following the devblog for Aviary Attorney for a long time and I can see they are people that are passionate about their game. I don't think they would have continued making the game after running out of money if this weren't true. They would have abandoned it or released it half finished. Yes, the game is unfinished, but it has the majority of its content and is not abandoned. I believe the devs deserve a second chance. They have messed up, but they have time yet to fix things. This mess is a real shame because Aviary Attorney is a lovely game. I've have really enjoyed playing it. I hope the devs can fix what's happened and restore their reputation.

I am not writing this review because of hurt feelings, but because I think this game is great. I want this game to be remembered for it's gameplay and dialogue. I want it to be remembered because it's fun! 
I know this was a lot to write for a dev that, in some eyes, didn't deliver but this criticism seems overly harsh. I've seen AAA games release in far worse states that have been praised to heaven and back. Does this seem fair or right? Perhaps it isn't a fair comparison, but you can see the hypocrisy surely?

This is a small first time dev team and I think a little patience is needed. I hope the devs will tell us an honest estimate for the final part soon. If they don't delivery the final part soon this review will no longer be a recommendation, but for now? I can wait.

20192058.review:
Keep in mind, I did not experience the unfinished ending.  So I may not be as helpful as others.

A video of this piece can be found here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QSiIYKuvGL4&feature=youtu.be

Aviary Attorney unfolds in 19th century France, where an attorney named Jayjay Falcon and his petite assistant Sparrowson defend many anthropomorphic animals in the courtroom.  Or as Sparrowson abrasively states, “help people get away with criminal acts”.  The duo investigate crime scenes and testimonies to craft a repertoire of evidence to defend their client.  And ultimately find the truth behind every illusive crime.

The writing is impeccable in Aviary Attorney.  It retains all the wit and courtroom drama of Ace Attorney with the banter of Hatoful Boyfriend.  Every joke had near flawless comedic timing and even after the 20th horse pun I was still in stitches.  The different acts follow different cases, and can each be played in 2-3 hours easily.  Through every character there’s a voice that resonates when reading their dialogue, proving that the written word in visual novels can still resonate even without voice acting.

Aviary Attorney retains the artistic integrity of caricature artist, Jean Ignace Isidore Gérard Grandville.  Rather than the colorful hyper-realism of Hatoful Boyfriend, the artstyle in Aviary Attorney is predominantly weathered yellow backdrops with hand drawn character models overlayed.  If you’ve ever played Phoenix Wright, the eccentric character models may pop into mind.  Aviary Attorney takes inspiration with this.  And combined with the anthropomorphic elements, it creates a great composition of colorful characters, even though it’s pastels are black and white.  

The music in Aviary Attorney is composed by French 19th century artist Camille Saint-Saëns, and its authenticity really brings the world to life.  With every orchestration reflecting the bourgeoisie atmosphere of early France.  It’s a very great and smart decision to use pieces of the era instead of attempting to replicate the early art in an OST.

As a Visual novel, Aviary Attorney has very minimal gameplay besides menu navigations and pursuing through text. However, unlike most visual novels.  Aviary Attorney takes inspiration from one of the most renown visual novels in gaming history.  The GBA and DS classics, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney (which surprisingly didn’t feature a feathered protagonist) from Capcom.  Aviary Attorney takes the formula of that first game, where after an introduction to the murder case you interview witnesses and examine crime scenes to gather crucial evidence.  Following your investigations, it’s off to the courtroom.  Where you must use aforementioned evidence to seduce the jury to your side.  By combing over witness statements and contradicting affidavits with evidence you will gain the jury’s mindshare, but by wasting their time you lose their enthusiasm with the person you’re defending.  Getting over each obstacle and test with minimal dissatisfaction from the jury, will result in the real murderer revealing himself and your client will be saved from the guilty verdict.

A hefty 25 hour game with multiple endings, Aviary Attorney fully justifies it’s 15 dollar price tag.  I’m not a big fan of Visual Novels, but Aviary Attorney is a great lampoon of the Ace Attorney formula with its interactivity.  This isn’t to say that Aviary Attorney is a bad Visual Novel, the writing is astonishing and comedic.  While France has been depicted in Assassin’s Creed, the music and art in Aviary Attorney bring the place and period to life in a way that is significantly pure.  The attention to detail the folks at Sketchy Logic have for the time period doubles in the respect they have for the history and time period.  Aviary Attorney is a compilation of great writing, art, music, and characters.  And one of 2015’s most significant surprises.
