20125154.review:
Aviary Attorney is a an incredibly creative and fun game, however I can't reccomend purchasing the game in it's current state. 

If you're a fan of the Ace Attorney games, you'll know what's going on here. You'll be examining evidence, trying to find errors in cross examinations, and interviewing people of interest to try and put together the various cases and mysterys as they unvold into a bigger picture. What seperates Aviary Attorney though is a creative art style that you won't find anywhere else, with a cheeky and irreverent sense of humor. The game also better punishes you for your mistakes, if you miss a piece of evidence, or badger a witness too much, you won't restart the case, you'll move on to the next one with consequences that effect the remaining trails. This is unique and opens it up to multiple playthroughs with vastly branching stories, and creates a more complete experiance. As for the story, the characters are fun and memorable, and well deliver plenty of chuckles (albeit likely no full belly-laughs).

The big problem dosen't rear it's ugly head untill late in the game, in my first playthrough I reached a branch in the story where I had not gathered the correct evidence for an impromptu trail, resulting in a text screen that read something along the lines of "Sorry, this ending is unfinished! Check back in two days!" And the game crashed. 

Not that it's super relevant, but it's but more than two days, almost a week. 

Nowhere on the store page does it advertise this being an uncomplete game, nor does it label it with a "Steam Greenlight" or "Beta" nomiker. This game had a kickstarter, and was delayed at least once, so why not wait the extra time and release the full game? I cannot reccomend purchasing this in the current condition (12/30/15), and possibly cannot reccomend a purchase even if this unfinished ending is patched in. This is lying to the customer, you NEED to advertise that your game is NOT finished, an improumptu text screen is simply NOT enough. Since this part of the game was almost 4 hours in, a refund was not possible, but if it had been I would have gotten one. Skethy Logic games needs to properly address this situation, as it is a dangerous practice in video gaming, and plagued what was otherwise an extremely pleasent experiance.

20115932.review:
Note: This review was orginally negative before being changed to positive as a result of the 1.02 patch. I have saved the original review down below for future reference.
----------------------------------------------------------------

Let's get the obvious out of the way: Aviary Attorney is clearly inspired by Ace Attorney. Everything from the gameplay, the type of humor, the dialogue and courtroom sessions are incredibly similar to the Capcom classic. Hell, the initials of the two series are the same and I doubt that due to coincidence. 

If you like Ace Attorney, I'll cut straight to the chase and say it: You'll probably like Aviary Attorney as well and it’s worth your money.

To go into detail, the game functions very similarly to Ace Attorney. You get a client coming in to defend them from a crime, usually murder. Then you have several days to wander to different areas of Paris, interview witnesses, gather clues and generally stick your beak where it don't belong. At the end of that period, you have a trial where you cross examine witnesses, present evidence and find contradictions.

So far, so Ace Attorney, right? The similarities go deeper: The main character is a bumbling and struggling defense attorney with a puntastic assistant. The prosecutor for the first case is inept before being replaced by your hoity toity high class rival who delights in insulting your skill. Many characters debate the true meaning of "Justice"...etc. etc.

So what sets it apart? Why buy it when Ace Attorney 6 is announced.

Well for one, there's no guarantee that Ace Attorney 6 will ever make it out west with the latest title in the series, The Great Ace Attorney, unlikely to ever release here so.....you don't have much of a choice.

But yes, there are some changes from the Capcom series that sets this title apart.

The most obvious is the art style. Aviary Attorney's most well known feature is that all the characters are anthropomorphic animals taken directly from the works of the 19th century French Caricaturist J.J Grandville. The art has been touched up in places, mostly to add animations such as blinking eyes and beaks/snouts/muzzles moving. They're not extensive by any means but are done quite seamlessly with a minimum amount of "original" artwork to fill in the blanks. (For example, one character pulls out a gun and a sharp eye can see that the outstretched arm's cross hatching isn't quite as detailed as the original art, indicating it’s a new change for the sake of the animation).

Some people might be turned off by the black and white visuals but I greatly enjoyed them as they gave a real picture book feel to the game and it’s always nice to see a game that increases the appreciation for classic art.

This extends to the music in the game which is also lifted mostly from 19th Century French composers of the Romantic era such as Hector Berlioz and Camille Saint-Saëns (as well as some original tracks made by the game's composer) which sounds absolutely beautiful.

When compared to Ace Attorney, the graphics in Capcom's offering are definitely better (though I like the style of Aviary's more) but the musical tracks are a no contest to Aviary Attorney, as much as I like the music in Ace.

This all fits in perfectly with the time setting of the game: 1848 Paris. If you know your history, you'll know that 1848 is a pivotal year for France and you will get embroiled in France's real life history one way or the other. (Err....but with some liberties taken of course. It's a game about anthropomorphic animals after all). 


But how is the gameplay? I won't lie; the investigating and interviewing processes in Aviary Attorney are pretty simple. Especially when compared to the multiple games in which Ace Attorney has had to grow out its staple of gameplay mechanics (i.e., adding in forensics, multiple angles to a crime scene.....etc.). Due to being limited by using J.J Grandville's art, the creators couldn't create incredibly complex locations for the game's crimes and therefore, all the cases seem rather simple when compared to the genius of Shu Takumi's crime drama writing. Aviary Attorney has the very simple mechanic of simply talking to witnesses and clicking on various objects in the background to reveal items and even the latter is only in special locations designated for investigating.

Overall, the game's cases are simpler and shorter than that of Ace Attorney. Still intriguing and interesting but not as good.

But Aviary Attorney has an ace up its sleeve, time and branching pathways. In Ace Attorney, it’s not possible to advance unless you have all the evidence you need to win the upcoming trial. You can keep switching around the various locations available to you till you find that one person or one event that will propel the story forward.

In Aviary Attorney, when the game tells you "The trial will commence in three days" You're on the fucking clock. Visiting most locations will consume an entire day and if you overlook a piece of evidence or go to the wrong locations, you can very well end up in court short of the evidence you need to clear your client. This is most evident in Case #3 which can end up in three different case #4s depending on how well you utilized your time and dug for evidence. It is entirely possible to go to the wrong locations and fuck up the trial. Another possibility is you get a partial success. In case #2, you can clear your client but still not expose the real criminal, giving you partial success and access to case #3 regardless.

 On top of all this, you have a money system in the game. The main character (J.J Falcon) has a wallet to carry his francs in which he can spend on various items in the game. You can usually get around paying by bringing another item or by clever dialogue choices but the currency mechanic means you can just skip some of the tasks in the game if you wish (As J.J Falcon says when asked for money or food in exchange for an item "I'm done with this fetch quest nonsense, just take the damn money").

Overall, Aviary Attorney isn't as good as Ace Attorney but does a lot of stuff that Capcom should really look at and implement into their series to break it from its linear structure. The writing Besides, Aviary Attorney is 15$ while Ace Attorney games are over double that so the shorter game time is justified by the discounted price.

As of the time of writing though, some bugs in the game remain. The steam overlay still does not work (A "bug" EA and Ubisoft will no doubt love to have), Saving is still not working (Saving and quitting sends you back to the last checkpoint, the beginning of the day) and achievements are still not implemented.

The devs have promised to fix these in addition to announcing a bonus chapter and a Linux version. So you might want to hold onto your francs if you these things bother you.

See you in court, monsieurs!

-----------------------------------------------------------------
Original Review
Posted: 30th December
Patch:1.01
Rating: Negative

This will revert to a positive review once the issues are resolved.

Aviary Attorney is an excellent, funny game with a unique aesthetic and as a detective/laywer game, it gives Ace Attorney a run for its money.

But at the moment, I can't recommend it. The game is incomplete.

One of the three endings is not implemented at all (It simply leads to a "sorry! We're not finished with this branch yet!" message)

Quick save was removed in a patch due to buginess so you have to use the in game checkpoints.

There's no log for the dialog spoken so be careful of errant clicks.

Steam overlay bizarelly does not work with the game so I can't take screenshots from Steam itself.

If the game was labelled early access, I would have given it a pass but at the moment it's marketed as version 1.01. A full title.

Hopefully, the devs will live up to their promise of an update in the very near future.

20102103.review:
I want to start by saying that I love the visual style of this game, and it got me into playing an attorney game even though I'd never played one before. The writing is cute and engaging, and the characters can be a lot of fun.

But on the whole, I've found the game disappointingly buggy. Sometimes it's just that the dialogue options haven't been thought through properly (for instance, if you need to choose a character from the list of characters you know to accuse of something or to ask about, and you choose the wrong person for the storyline, the characters will say something like 'Who is that person?' even if it was a friend of theirs, which makes things very confusing for the player, since you start worrying you pressed the wrong button or something). Once, in Act 3, I asked about an unimportant piece of data and midway through discussing it the dialogue skipped back to a previous conversation on a different subject.

Sometimes the bugs are bigger. It's already been noted that depending on how you play through, Act 4 may not be accessible to you at all. I made a mistake in Act 3 and Act 4 isn't accessible to me, so I went back to play from Act 2, but when I try to load Day 1 of Act 2, it bugs out and gives me an illustration, but no characters or dialogue and I can't move forward. I feel that this game has a pretty hefty price for mostly text-based gameplay if it's going to have this many game-halting problems with it. It's not just the unfinished Act 4, there are a number of serious and confusing problems that really affect the experience or sometimes terminate it altogether. Especially if the game is going to be so unforgiving (going to a location that I had a lead for a day earlier than I was apparently supposed to caused me to fail my goal in Act 2), and going to halt your progress if you make certain decisions, then it really needs to be able to reload properly from previous days.

I think this game could be really great, but it's lacking polish and completion in several serious areas, so at the moment I don't think it can be said to be worth $15 or even $13.

20060694.review:
首先说，如果是逆转粉的话，强烈推荐这款游戏w因为…简直是逆转的法国二月革命前版本嘛！
作为一个逆转粉，我从这个游戏的角角落落都能看出既视感来……不管是人物设定（主角、主角的笨蛋助手、主角的同窗兼死对头相爱相杀的检察官，第一章直接出来送的弱鸡，啊不对，弱兔检察官什么的），还是案件设定（特别是第三章基友的那个案件，简直是御剑和御剑父亲那俩案件的合体）。不过它又不是一款单纯地模仿逆转的游戏，因为它的历史背景，是设定在法国二月革命（1848年）之前，这就意味着它更多带有那个时代的味道，不管是装满对社会不满的人的Tavern，还是Revolution，还是Cult of Reason，还是法王路易菲利普（居然是个企鹅hhhhhhhh），还能逛遍巴黎的各种景点（就是地名查得我头疼），与那个时代的各色人等交流什么的，还有经常会蹦出来的法语词和西班牙语词（多大仇，玩刺客信条的时候好歹还会在意大利语词或者西班牙语词边上标注英文呢），都在反复提醒我，这不是逆转，这是发生一个特殊的时代，一个特殊的地点的一系列故事。
游戏的难度我感觉比逆转要高，逆转在探索阶段，不找齐证物是不会往下推进剧情的，但这个游戏就不同，没找齐证物，时间照样会消耗，游戏照常进行，然后会把你导向不同的结局，一个地方的关键证物有没有找齐，游戏也不会有任何提示（直到庭审阶段大概才会有提示说哪个证物没找齐），导向了不想看到的结局时，只有一个办法了，SL吧…但这游戏的语言文字又不能skip，所以有些时候实在点得有些烦…第一次庭审的时候我都没明白作案手法什么的，只能被剧情推着走了（然后第一章末尾就被wtf了一脸…我这是在看legal high第一季第一集吗？！）。不过这边也能看出来这个游戏的主旨和逆转之间最大的区别，逆转中是对于真相的探讨，而这个游戏，是在探讨正义。
游戏的语言风格是偏幽默的，经常被Falcon和Sparrowson这俩逗得大笑不止，主角们真是太好玩了。以及游戏里有不少梗，如果能看出来的话（比如tweet，还有悲惨世界的梗），大概也能会心一笑吧。
音乐大好评w只是游戏本身有点贵所以就没买soundtrack…
语言方面不难，六级过了玩起来是没什么障碍的（就是名词啥的会有点烦人，还有法语词什么的）。
目前我是打出了4B，还没往下打，把4B推完之后再回去推4A和4C。多结局也是这个游戏的优点之一。
以及谁能告诉我这游戏的存档在哪？！！！这游戏没有云存档…换台电脑就玩不了了…

20059816.review:
I am writing this review immediately following "100%"ing the game. I found this game on kickstarter when it was just about to be funded. I have been a fan of Phoenix Wright ever since it first came out for the Nintendo DS, and have played every title up to now multiple times. So when I saw this game I thought that having a new set of characters in a new universe with the same game formula, that it could definitely be something special. First off, the art and the music of the game are absolutely fantastic. The art and the music are definitely some of what my favorite parts of the game is. As a Phoenix Wright fan, the gameplay itself does not quite amount to the same level of depth found in Phoenix Wright, nonetheless the addition of a limited amount of time make the game feel original while still retaining enough elements from the game to please old fans as well as newcomers. 

There are ways the game could be improved. First, the game is painfully short. In under 3 hours I had unlocked both endings, as well as seen the multiple ways each case could have ended. The story seems rushed and ends in a whimper in a horiffically anticlimatic way. The first two cases were absolutely wonderful but the final act seemed to be put out before it was ready which leads to a poor finale. 

All in all, the game was is $15, and I will say that you get what you pay for, it took up an evening that I enjoyed and I will probably replay it again, but I think that this game would do well with some additional content as it is lacking greatly.

20058231.review:
经人介绍，在发售前就一直关注着的游戏，今天终于把目前版本里的所有内容全部打通了。
给其他人几点关于购买的建议：
[olist]
[*]虽然不是抢先体验版，但是其实这个游戏还没有做完，有一个结局还在coming soon的状态（现在已经做完了，全部结局可见了）
[*]游戏还有许多小bug以及体验上的不佳，作者应该还会再更新改进。目前最严重的bug大概就是steam overlay不能用吧（其他恶性的bug在1.01版里修复了）
[*]虽然说游戏性价比这种事情因人而异，不过跟steam其他国区游戏的价格和品质比起来，或许这个游戏打折再厉害一些才会让大部分人觉得划算吧。
[/olist]
综上所述，现在买或许还不是时候，对它感兴趣的话，可以加个关注等之后的重大更新或者更高折扣时再考虑入。不过如果像我一样对此强烈感兴趣的话，那就赶紧买买买吧。

下面是对游戏本身的评价：
游戏的画风非常惊艳，十九世纪讽刺漫画插画家J. J. 格兰威尔的风格（游戏介绍里写的，我其实并不知道那是谁，不过这个魔性的画面确实很久以前在哪里见过的感觉），故事的背景也是设定在1848年时动乱不定的法国，剧情涉及大量的政治斗争阶级斗争的问题，很大气，剧中的人物和事件都是有真人真事可循的，[spoiler]主角居然还是法国某著名大律师的孙子，这金田一的节奏…[/spoiler]再配上那种复古极具时代感的BGM，整个游戏可以说是逼格极高。光这些其他游戏没有的要素和体验我觉得就足够值回票价了，当然关于这个的看法可能因人而异。
游戏是类逆转裁判的系统，也就是日常问询调查+法庭指证战斗，不过也不是完全一样的，还加入了一些更传统的侦探游戏要素：调查自由很高，有时限，就算证据没有收集齐也能推进剧情，只是会进入不同的结局。对，这游戏居然还是多结局的，游戏一共四章，第三章是最复杂也是最精彩的一章，这一章主角的发挥和抉择，将完全影响到第四章的剧情，会有三个完全不一样的第四章（虽然其中有一个还没做完）。玩完之后回顾一下，在谜题的设计上，我只能给第三章一个好评，其他章基本上也就只是看剧情而已，谜题都非常水。
剧情和人物塑造其实很不错，因为角色都是面无表情的动物，所以可以很无违和的一边讲正经的剧情一边又可以把氛围做的很风趣一边又把每个怪胎式的角色塑造得很鲜明。只玩一条结局线的话，大概会觉得某些地方有点空，之前挖的一些坑没填上。但是再玩一条结局线会发现，哇哦，填上了（鼓掌）。我相信还有些没填的部分都在未完成的第三条结局线上了，小期待一下。但是说到这里必须批评作者在结局设置上的一个巨大的失误，相信几乎所有不看攻略的玩家初见一定会进入结局C，但是就是这个结局作者没做完，玩到那里我直接一个大写的懵逼，我觉得那些差评应该就是这么来的。你可以稍候再做真结局、隐藏结局或者什么奇奇怪怪的猎奇结局，但是你不能不做一个大部分玩家初见都会进入的普通结局啊。
程序方面，我觉得不是特别好，steam overlay的bug就已经挺严重了，还有许多细节上的bug。比如立绘缩放时，明显看到嘴部的图片和整体分离了（因为嘴部要动所以是单独的图片），不同界面的页码没有重置导致翻页键经常在不应该消失的时候消失了。存档都只是存在每天刚开始的时候，并不会存在剧情中间，估计所有在超长剧情半路存档的玩家再读档时都会大骂坑爹吧。鼠标图标经常不正常，分辨率也各种变各种不稳定。游戏玩一段时间后，内存会爆占到1.3G以上，这也是程序的锅。另外就是一个最不亲切的体验，完全没有剧情跳过功能，无论是被存档坑了跳回每天开始还是想打多结局时重玩第三章，剧情都没法跳，只能疯狂地点点点点，这个真是太不亲切了，希望新版本能加上。
英语方面，这游戏的英语比其他文字游戏大概稍难一些，主要是有些不常用很正式的词和法语词，但是总体影响不大，相信常玩英文文字游戏的人应该都不会有问题。
————————————————————

结局C加进来了，这个游戏终于算是做完了，虽然bug还是没修好……
[spoiler]这个结局C，虽然算是一个bad end，但是我觉得却是做得最精彩的一个结局，调查篇虽然非常水，但是高潮在审判篇了，首先这个案子虽然很简单，但是很有逆转的风味，不逊于第三章的。再就是这个剧情，真的是跌宕起伏，大起大落，扣人心弦，不仅把之前没填的悬念坑给填了（虽然有的还是没填，比如那个Guizot首相，在B结局里露了一脸就没了，还以为会在结局C里重点出场……结果就只是提了提名字罢了，晕），还把一段BE演绎的十分精彩。剧情意料之外又是情理之中，无论Falcon如何抉择，无论Volerti警探怎样认为，无论革命军用怎样的方式践行自己的王道，无论杀手是谁杀手做了什么，三条世界线最终都会收束在一起，几个人几天的时间内的所作所为终究还是不能改变历史的走向。[/spoiler]这个游戏的故事的“起”非常大气，最初还担心它hold不住，但是却能够以小见大、以点成面，剧情把握得非常得体。发售折扣时以40元购入，我觉得此作品的品质很值回票价，比较满意，唯一的遗憾就是各种bug，不知道何年何月才会修复完毕。

20046185.review:
A game that takes heavy inspirations from the famed Ace Attourney series. If you have played Ace Attourney games Ill happily recommend this to you. It has the similar charm and wit, although unlike Ace Attourney you seem to actualy have a time limit. And a lawyer who actualy seems to know about court etiquette and rules. 

Also the investigation parts wandering around Paris provide a refressing chance to screw up. You could simply use too many days simply playing Blackjack in the tavern. Or maybe you missclicked and ended the investigation inside your current location.

Heres a quick summary of the positives and negatives

+ Wonderful artstyle. 
Jean Jaques Grandevilles 18th century art comes alive and the animal characters fit the story.

+ Music is fantastic. 
Classical music fiths the 18th century like chocolate on a croissant

+The story is intriguing. 
The different cases in the game provide decent variety in terms of turns and events. The game managed to even surprise me when I was in a too Ace Attourney way of thinking.

-The game is woefully short. 
I completed my first playthrough in 5.6 hours according to steam. Even that time had few breaks where the game was left running. This is the greatest negative to the game. As a single case in later Ace Attourney games could easily last that amount of time by itself. Provided you take your time.

-The ending was a bit....anti climactic.
 In the 4th case I was in the B route. And it left me...Wanting more. Or a more epic conclusion.

These negatives dont outright ruin the game. But you should keep them in mind still. Nevertheless I enjoyed my time with JayJay and Sparrowson and I am looking forward to any possible continuation of their story. Or maybe another characters story inside the Aviary Attourney universe.

20011852.review:
General verdict is that it’s really great, and comes strongly recommended, especially if you’ve ever enjoyed any of the Ace Attorney games. There are some significant and insignificant bugs and typos at the time of this writing (December 27th, 2015), but the package as a whole is more than good enough for me to forgive some rough edges. (Pro tip: don’t adjust options at the title screen. Wait until you’re in the game proper. I had to uninstall and reinstall the game a few times until I figured out that was what was making it stop responding to me.)

It’s a visual novel about lawyers practicing in 19th Century France, except everyone is a creature from the illustrations of 19th Century satirist J. J. Grandville, set to music by the romantic era composer Camille Saint-Saëns.

The whole thing has a very Hatoful Boyfriend kind of feel to it, and not just because of the static images or the birds: this is a game that has a completely ridiculous premise and uses that to draw the player in to a grim tale of political strife, asking questions about justice and revenge. Parts of it seem to be direct responses to Ace Attorney scenes, too - a lot of Ace Attorney moments get flipped on their heads here.

That’s not to say it isn’t really funny when it wants to be - it’s freaking hilarious when it feels like it! That’s another thing that feels really Hatoful Boyfriend about the whole proceeding, but it’s certainly its own thing, and it got its talons in me really deep. Can’t wait for the third ending to get fixed!

tl;dr: While there are some bugs still, it’s highly recommended for visual novel fans, especially if you enjoyed Hatoful Boyfriend and/or any of the Ace Attorney games.

20010747.review:
Should you play Aviary Attorney? Yes with a hint of maybe. All in all it will be best to wait to purchase this game until the developers release the debugged and complete version.

AA is a fun playthrough for fans of both of the game's major inspirations (Phoenix Wright/Ace Attorney and Hatoful Boyfriend). It has its fair share of comedy and puns (although many of the puns will require minimal knowledge of the French language), and in the later half of the game, it has a great original overarching plot centering around the setting of pre-revolution France. The game also features a great original classical soundtrack and engaging graphics styled around 19th century etchings and caricatures.

At the moment, the game remains incomplete though, and this makes is a bit hard to recommend the game, especially with the high price point (for a short visual novel). The first half of the game will feel boring to Phoenix Wright players, as it nearly carbon copies the first Phoenix Wright game through the first two cases. Many bugs abound in the game that make it hard to understand why it was released (do not open the options menu from the title screen, and the save system is a mess). While the game boasts three endings, one of them is listed as "Coming Soon" and there is little knowledge as to whether this means pay-to-play DLC, a forthcoming update, or that it will ever come at all.

Should the bugs be worked out and the game completed, it's well worth your time and money. If this ends up being the final version of the game, I still recommend it, but would urge players to wait and not pay more than $5 for the product presented.

20001065.review:
Definitely a few steps beyond its comedic premise, Aviary Attorney is definitely a very complete package, even if it's a small one.
Its immediate comparison is Phoenix Wright, but don't view it as a simple clone - the "Ace" series has had more than its fair share of problems in comprehensible solutions to testimonies or investigations, so it's excellent that "Aviary" attempts to remedy those. For starters, the player is expected to work out the best part of the city to investigate each day before a case. You get between 3 days to 2 weeks to perform a cursory investigation for each case, and you have to make sure each day counts. This had its ups and downs to me, since at times I felt I wasn't psychic enough to know the best sequence of locations to visit. For what it's worth, the game allows you to rewind to any previous day very easily, but it may mean skipping through dialog.

Their better improvement is in cross examinations. Rather than scrolling through a series of statements and blindly presenting one piece of evidence as "contradicting" it (a simple gameplay rule that Phoenix Wright breaks at times) the witness's testimony is shown as one paragraph on a sheet, and JayJay underlines a few statements he can ask about. When you do, you get a few choices about topic; delving too far on an unrelated line can cause you to lose favor with the jury, whereas you will need to delve if you think you've found a subject that you can present contradictory evidence for.

For fans of Ace Attorney, this is surely a game to try out. If it has one failing, it's one that lots of small-time adventure games seem to fall into, in which later in the game, the gameplay begins to serve the storyline, rather than the other way around. For the last 30 minutes of the game or so you'll likely just be progressing dialog and picking obvious location/evidence choices rather than unravelling a complicated murder mystery. However, I happened to only do one of several options that led to this - It turns out that your actions in Case 3 can actually cause the final case to happen in one of several ways. SO, there is a possibility that this result is only one way things may happen.

19992185.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

Liberté, égalité, fraternité

Aviary Attorney is heavily inspired by the classic Capcom game Ace Attorney, but instead of having anime guys and girls with big junk in certain areas, you have birds, all different types of birds. Living in harmony with all different types of animals, including lions, wolves and others, in a civilized yet corrupt Paris

The game takes place in France just before another French Revolution is being plotted underneath in the catacombs of Paris. You play Falcon, a lawyer with a dogdy family background and your bubbling sidekick Sparrowson who together have to defend their client in question in a court of law

The game's mechanics do follow heavily that of Capcom's classic, Ace Attorney, as you have to go and gather evidence, find any loopholes in the verdict and cross examine witnesses. The story does take a turn half way and deviates from this system

The game is text based game with wonderful hand drawn environments, however, seeing this colourless, black and white environments does get boring after a while. The story is well written and has huge amounts of comedy and references to modern day pop culture

The only things I found a bit off were the small amounts of spelling and grammatical mistakes, as well as no support for the Steam overlay and some other missing features, such as achievements and a missing ending which is to be finished in an upcoming update

Overall, Aviary Attorney is a brilliant game which deals with the changes that were occuring during the French Revolution, as well as before and after. This game had me hooked so much that I finished the game in one whole sitting! Which is very rare in my case. If you have ever played Ace Attorney or like that sort of gameplay, with a pinch of comedy and pop culture references thrown into the mix, then Aviary Attorney is the game for you!

19980554.review:
Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of Indie Mystery Visual-Novel, Aviary Attorney. Aviary Attorney was released on Steam on December 21, 2015 by Developer/Publisher Sketchy Logic.

(NOTE: This game was NOT reviewed using a key provided by the Developer and/or Publisher, it was a game from my own account)

Video Review:

https://youtu.be/FSbcrZv4Y_c

The "Too Long, Didn't Watch" Review:

Great fun, hilarious, beautiful. Top-Notch Visual Novel. 5/5 (despite the GLARINGLY obvious rush at release)

The "Meat & Potatoes" Review:

This game is simply gorgeous. That is probably the first thing you notice about Aviary Attorney overall. The music matches the art as well, simply beautiful. I have never played either Hatoful or Pheonix Wright, so most of the "comparisons" I am seeing do not mean much and felt like I could give a fresh perspective to this game. I was once studying to be an attorney (my "Clark Kent" still works Gov't) so felt immediately drawn to this. IT also happen to help that I absolutely LOVE horrible puns. If you do not, you may want to just walk away now. Not from the review, just from the game entirely. However, I find it absolutely hilarious. The dialogue and writing overall is superb, the art is beautiful, the piano is divine. This is everything a solid VN should be. The story is truly engaging and fun. An ending was unavailable at release, and release was delayed a few days. I attempted to get a hold of the reviewer for a key, and was unsuccessful. Clearly, they were overwhelmed in their attempts to meet their own deadline. I have seen complaints, but honestly they obviously cared enough to work EXTRA hard in the days up to, and since launch. That dedication to their product is a good thing. Does it suck that they missed their goal by a couple/few days? Sure. It seemed to be more out of a desire to release the best product they could and they continue to improve to this day (there have already been updates). Give this one a go. I fully endorse it and am loving every minute. Several LOL moments. Fans of any type of Visual Novel will enjoy this for sure, as will anyone with a good sense of humor. If action is what you want, you may not find it here. Tons of "Pros" and short on "Cons", this VN is truly worth the $15 pricetag. A true 5/5 for this gamer.

Happy Gaming!

19947524.review:
Aviary Attorney (AA) is a game that, despite being inspired by Phoenix Wright series, has its own unique charm: orchestra music, intricate art style, and a some pretty nice puns. Every investigation and action does influence the outcome of court proceedings and/or story, which may prove to be tricky as time is limited and investigation choices increase as chapter goes that one is never sure which one is a false lead/useful lead (unless you are using a guide). Also, the 4th case is dependent on your actions in case 3, and there are 3 alternative cases (with 1 of them being unreleased). The storyline is a tad short, but surprisingly complex and intriguing as it revolves around the grey area of law (the ending of the first case does gut the heart already) and the meaning of justice. If you aren't inclined of the animal characters but wants to know whether the story is worth it, then AA will not disappoint.

However, there are a few notable drawbacks. First being that there are a few typos in-game. They're relatively minor and few, but it'd be nice if the game is a wee polished. Also, saving in the middle of a conversation seems impossible; if one "Save and Quit" during a convo, it usually loads from when the scene started. And lastly, one of the ending paths (4C) is incomplete, resulting in lots of complaints and negative feedback (expected release date: 29th Dec 2015). There has been a few bug reports on game blackout, but I encountered none so far. My only complaint is the inability to share screenshot, though it's unsure whether the game has disabled screenshot or it's my setting problem (because there has been people who have posted screenies).

Nevertheless, apart from the few drawbacks, the game is mostly interesting and is worth the purchase imo. AA is easily completed within 5~8 hours. (And yes, please ignore my game time. I was paranoid about the save that I left the game running while AFKing).

19943111.review:
Honored Members of the Steam Customer list, My name is unimportant, but I am here to dispense the rational defense that this game has deserved. As you all have seen in recent reviews, it has been berated for being half complete, or ending after the 3rd act. Yet after 3.5 hours (I am a vet. of Pheonix Wright) we can come to the conclusion that it is absolutely a blast to play. The humor is witty, and quick. The art is stupendous, the story maybe not as complicated, but these people need to hit their stride, and they can do something great with this. Maybe not 10 games worth, but maybe a sequel or something better.
Anyway, the music is great, the characters are charming. Is it buggy? Maybe a bit, but nothing so outrageous that this game cannot outweigh its pros, and enjoyment. People will talk about a horrid, or unfinished ending, but this game ends on a note that makes you want more.
With evidence of completing the game after 4 acts, the best ending I have reached in a game since Fallout New: Vegas, I believe we have a bit of a gem on our hands, and that you should not waste this opportunity. The ending is not unfinished, it has more than 1, it is overly original, and I believe it is worthy of its price.
The defence rests its case.

19939640.review:
Edit - 

So the game has been fixed with the witheld content. Yet, I find myself unwilling to revert my score as it is.


For one, the game is just too short for an interactive story game. 

The idea of cases failing because of your inability to find the correct evidence comes across as pretty arbitrary. If you click everything you come across with no thought, the idea loses its execution, yet at the same time, in the biggest chapter, simply not having the luck of accessing the right areas first, with little information to go on, failing the case just comes off as a whimsical failure more than anything.

The art is nice, but the characters are rather simple, lifted from a historic artist's work with little adjustment.

As a whole, the game lacks scope to be considered as a worthy play when you have played far better games of its ilk.

This is definitely the game to fill the Ace Attorney shaped hole in your heart.

I've only finished the first two cases as of yet (there are 4 total), but that's more than enough to recommend this game.
It bears many similarities to the popular Capcom series. The gameplay is almost identical. In the field you collect evidence and interview persons of intrest and then you try to prove your clients innocence in court by cross-examinating the witnesses and finding contradictions in their testimony. Fans of Ace Attorney will also find few familiar tropes within the characters, but other than that the game very much stands on it's own. Its unique asthetics, characters and humor are mixed with a story set in the dawn of the French Revolution and makes for a very compelling narrative.

Few shortcomings: The music (although very good on it's own and definitely fits the setting) doesn't quite pack the same punch as the Ace Attorney soundtrack. Also the cases (at least the first two) are nowhere near as complex. They're pretty straight-forward and the twists and turns are not very suprising although still very well written.

PS. I've encoutnered a few bugs. Mostly the game locking up on a screen and not letting you progress, but it's just a minor annoyance since the game allows you to replay individual days rather than whole cases.

19893642.review:
Aviary Attorney evokes fond memories of the "Ace Attorney" series. If you've never played them before, the general gist of it is that you're a lawyer defending a client, and to do so you investigate the scene of the crime, gather evidence and interrogate witnesses, and on court day use said evidence to attempt to get your client a "not guilty" verdict.

So compared to reality not really lawyer-like work at all, but as in this game you're playing as anthropomorphized bird Mssr. JayJay Falcon, you'll probably want to suspend your disbelief. Set in 1800s France, with old-timey art from J. J. Grandville to match, Aviary Attorney's presentation is simple but charming. The characters aren't voiced, but have different-toned blips to indicate who is speaking.

Gameplay-wise, Aviary Attorney is almost more of a visual novel. While you do travel from place to place to find clues and talk to people, there isn't as much interaction as you'd typically find in an adventure game. The puzzles are fairly simple, which may serve to annoy more hardcore adventure gamers. There is a bit of pixel hunting to be had (exacerbated slightly by the fact that everything is black-on-sepia), but it's nothing annoying.

The story and characters go on to steal the show, though. With a liberal sprinkling of puns and good humor, I felt that the characterizations of the animals you interact with were very well done. The atmosphere of the game also does not veer into the spiritual, which I always thought was a (albeit quirky) weakness of the Ace Attorney games.

All that said, the game felt like it went by pretty quickly. Since it's a sub-$20 buy, though, I think it's worth the money.

19889871.review:
I've played through all available content as of writing this, and this is my first review so excuse me. 

tl;dr Good game. I recommend the game highly, you should get it. 

Let's look at the individual aspects though. 

[b]Playtime:[/b]
My playtime is accurate at 4.7 hours. I consider my playtime to be around average. I didn't scrounge for every single piece of dialogue, but I also had a slightly higher reading pace. If you have difficulties with logic puzzle games, this may be a bit longer as I think I figured out necessary actions fairly quickly.This will bring the total playtime to around 5 hours when the last route releases. I would consider that a respectable amount for the price point. 

[b]Music:[/b]
The music for the game is very solid. The soundtrack brings appropriate ambiance that fits both the story's setting of old France and it plays to the situation at hand. I was never jarred by off-putting choices of music at any point. My only criticism of the music is there wasn't any that felt catchy or memorable enough. I have no urge to open up the soundtrack to just listen to a particular song. 

[b]Visuals:[/b]
The visuals speak for themselves. Absolutely stunning and unique. From the backgrounds to the character art, the game looks great and I find myself eager to explore new zones just to see what they look like. Nothing to say here but praise. Great work. 

[b]Writing:[/b]
Here's where the game gets really juicy. The game accomplishes what it tries to do perfectly. The humor in the game goes well beyond just puns and animal jokes. Exclamatory remarks, running jokes, and wordplay are all done with great timing and execution.

The characters themselves are indeed memorable and unique. No one felt like a copy of each other or even as adhering to an established character archetype. You will undoubtedly find a favorite among the cast. The character development is also quite nice as well, flowing naturally and without feeling forced. 

The story is quite engaging and progresses. Your choices do matter and the chapters flow into one another, not standalone episodes. You follow the main character's story and see how far they will go. The conflicting ideologies presented in the game are quite well done. Both sides are presented fairly, neither being demonized, and you get to see some of the humanity behind each train of thought. I really love how they did this and I appreciate the writer's efforts. 


[b]Gameplay:[/b]
It's inevitable to talk about this game without talking about a certain other series. However, I wouldn't go so far as to say took mechanics and ideas, but it feels more like a love letter to a beloved memory. The gameplay is very good and separated into 2 main sections: trials and exploration. You explore, get evidence, and meet people to prepare for the upcoming trials. Your success in exploring will carry you through the trial. The game presents a very nice tutorial section that exposes you to all the mechanics before getting more and more complex in a very natural way. I would liken this to a logic puzzle, where common sense and intuition rule and will be your friend. I personally enjoyed the gameplay very much, and you probably will too if you're even just looking into the game to see what it's about. I will say, it will take more than one playthrough and some testing to try and get all the endings. 


[b]Closing remarks:[/b]
If the price point puts you off, don't worry about it. The game is worth the money and you're supporting the devs and their hard work. They need to eat too.

The game is also still being polished. During my first playthrough, I encountered a few bugs, but those were quickly patched out. The devs are responsive and looking to create a great experience. 

The writing, gameplay, and art of the game are all astounding and some of the best I've seen out of a project like this. 

I look forward to the game's success, the future works of the devs, and maybe even a sequel if they're so kind.

19889635.review:
This is, quite simply, the most engaging and entertaining game I've played in a long time. The visuals are stunning, and very well implemented from the original source material, the score is excellently chosen (who doesn't love Saint-Saens?), the scripting is witty, and the storyline gripping.

The interface is very simple to use, and the evidence-finding and trial systems require thought and reasoning - it's most certainly not a sure thing that you'll be successful!

The only thing I have found (and I had to think hard) that is mildly irritating is that if you do badly and want to go back to a previous day's save, there is no way to speed past all the dialogue you've already done that day to get to the bit you want (this can take quite a lot of clicking). I believe, however, that they are in the process of implementing a fix for this by improving the saving points.

Also, thinking about it, I have finished it in two evenings - although this could well just be because I couldn't put it down! You can replay the later chapters for a couple of different ending options, should you so wish.

I thoroughly recommend this game - it would not be a stretch to say that this has been the best money I have spent on Steam this year!

19887612.review:
J'ai attendu des mois de jouer à ce jeu. Je l'ai torché en deux jours, en fait en quelques heures. C'est trop peu !!! 
Certes, je ne vais pas m'attarder sur ce qui est mentionné dans chaque évaluation, les musiques sont de premiers choix, des compositeurs du XIXème siècle comme Saint-Saëns ou Bizet, on croise même Debussy pour le thème de Caterline Demiaou.
Les noms sont bien choisis d'ailleurs en fonction des animaux, et même si j'ai fais le jeu en anglais, il y a un délicieux mélange entre l'anglais et le français, avec des jeux de mots qui rendent le jeu très agréable. On joue essentiellement avec un duo, l'avocat et son assistant, autrement dit deux personnages complémentaires.
Il y a tout un background historique de la ville de Paris, avec des lieux emblématiques comme la cathédrale ou le Louvre; on commence l'histoire en janvier 1848, et les passionnés d'histoire reconnaîtront tout de suite une date cruciale dans l'histoire du XIXème siècle... Je n'en dis pas plus car c'est au centre du jeu, qui est divisé en 4 actes tel une pièce de théâtre. 
On alterne entre investigations, interviews, procès et quêtes secondaires. La seule chose frustrante, c'est lors des explorations : chaque jour, on doit se rendre dans un endroit de la carte suivant l'avancement de l'enquête. Seulement, certains lieux peuvent être visités plusieurs fois dans une journée, mais d'autres gaspillent une journée entière. Du coup, il faut choisir et parfois faire des sacrifices, notamment sur les quêtes secondaires, pour récupérer les preuves nécessaires aux procès. Mais souvent, on a que trois jours pour récupérer des preuves dans différents endroits, avant le procès. D'où le problème du temps de visite d'un lieu.
C'est aussi pourquoi j'espère qu'il y aura des mises à jour régulières pour apporter un peu plus de contenu, même s'il existe plusieurs fins, a priori au moins deux. 
Je n'ai pas encore compris l'intérêt d'avoir une assemblée de jurés, dont on peut gagner ou perdre en faveur. Ils interviennent peu dans les procès. 
Dans tous les cas, ce jeu mérite d'être fait et d'être approfondi encore plus : peut-être que les développeurs pourraient créer un épisode qui se déroulerait en 1871 ?... ;)

19864686.review:
一款类逆转裁判的文字冒险推理游戏，亮点在于19世纪J.J.Grandville的超现实主义讽刺素描画风和卡米尔·圣桑的配乐。 具体请看从机核的文章——>http://www.g-cores.com/articles/17068 

英文难度不大，像我这种刚过了四六级的渣渣就能够看懂大部分剧情和一些梗(Facebook,twitter,红鲱鱼)，偶有一些法语单词，不过不影响整体理解。 

系统：
简化版的逆转裁判，自由调查+法庭战斗两部分。前两章是只有一条路线，第三章会根据你的选择有三条路线，分别导向4A章，4B章，4C章。其中4C章还没做完，这也是其他测评给差评的主要原因。
人物塑造：
跟逆转系列很类似，无名律师主角，负责搞笑的呆萌助手(关键时刻很可靠)，亦敌亦友的傲娇检察官(当年还是法律学校的同学)。另外本作将人设动物化与逆转系列将人设夸张化(颜艺化)其实有异曲同工之妙，都能够突出人物性格特点，方便人物塑造。
剧情：
第一章作为教学章难度很小，推理过程也难称严密，不过最后的逆转出人意料，也与前面的一些伏笔呼应，可以说将第一章的剧情瞬间拔高了一个档次。
第二章开始有一些难度，虽然没有令人惊艳的逆转，梗也比较老套，但是还算令人满意，同时也为第三章做了一些铺垫。
第三章是自由度最大的一章，你的不同选择会导致3个不同的第四章。目前只打出来了4A和4C，4B读了好几遍法庭辩护时的存档死活打不出来…估计是之前自由行动没有收集完证据，如果有人打出了4B请务必告诉我怎么做到的！
第四章由于没有打出来想要的4B路线所以没玩。
总体来说剧情与逆转系列结构很相似，都是用1-3章三个看似不相关的小故事串成第4章的大故事。但区别在于本作推理部分较弱，但是在其他方面更有深度(剧情更黑暗)。虽然主角与助手的各种插科打诨为本作平添了许多欢乐的色彩，但这个故事的大基调还是较为严肃的。故事背景设计在是在1830年法国七月革命后的十几年，时局动荡不安，人民怨声载道，巴黎就像一个火药桶，随时可能会爆发革命。在这种真实的大格局历史背景下玩家的代入感会更强，再加上本作独特的美术风格，仿佛能身临其境的回到当时的巴黎，感受到空气中弥漫的不安与躁动，替身处在历史洪流中的主角做出选择：加入革命推翻皇权，还是镇压革命维持稳定？这都将导致不同的结局(Act4)。

最后为一拉到底的玩家们总结一下：
优点：独特而自成一体的美术风格，看起来十分舒服；整体架构基本致敬逆转裁判，而且有更有深度(黑暗)的剧情；较为成功的人物塑造。
缺点：不支持键盘控制；第4章的C路线目前还没做完；流程较短（不过多结局应该可以弥补这一点）；推理部分较弱。
建议逆转裁判系列的粉丝可以先将本作加个关注，等所有结局做完了(或者出汉化了)再入。

以下强烈剧透：
[spoiler] 

第一章的逆转是指获得无罪判决后我们的委托人坦诚她才是真正的犯人，我们的推理只是错误的将好人送进了监狱。这同时也解释了为什么之前的推理会有那些漏洞。
第二章的故事就是身为革命党的法官通过金钱胁迫卖花女协助他刺杀国王，没想到卖花女被护花使者顶罪。最后真相大白法官入狱。
第三章就是调查地下反抗组织的信息。自由度很高，能打出三个结局，
A 主角辩护失败，检察官鸡友(literal)被反抗组织杀死后被胁迫加入反抗组织
B 没打出来，不过应该是主角辩护成功，救下基友
C 主角对检察官基友见死不救，基友被反抗组织杀死，主角黑化成为当年七月革命时的自己(Justice is dead! Viridian Killer is Back!)
…你能想象逆转裁判三个结局里有两个是御剑死了么…所以如果有同学打出了4B结局请务必教教我...


	[/spoiler]

19863568.review:
An excellent, excellent game.  I bought it expecting it to be a humorous homage to the Phoenix Wright franchise, but I was happily mistaken: this game stands perfectly fine on its own two bird-feet.  

The art and animation are clean and pleasant to look at, and not overly complicated, like a visual novel.  The writing was also nice, ranging from bad puns to interesting (if slightly heavy-handed, but I gave this a pass considering the time period) social commentary.  In fact, my only regret about this game is that there isn't more content, though it's implied that there's more coming soon!

A quick note: Un-learn your Ace Attorney habits.  The game does not grind to a stop while you collect every bit of evidence you need, so if you're not careful you can end up going into a trial without important information or evidence.  Fortunately, the game is still forgiving, and you are able to go back and re-peat specific days to get whatever it was you forgot.  There's also more than one solution to a puzzle, and multiple endings!

I have completed each case and there is at least one more promised in the future. This is not  a very long game but the writing is on point, the references range from Phoenix Wright which this game draws heavily from to many quite intellectual references. 

The game has 3 different endings and each will help to build the full picture about each character. Each case also tends to have at least one unexpected turn of events to keep you on your toes.

The music and art are both fantastic each character looks stunning and the animation is simple and not too distracting and well thought out. The polish is simply fantastic.

19860848.review:
I've always been a big fan of the Ace Attorney series and was happy to see someone else take on the genre.

I'll list the pros and cons I experienced from the first case:

+Wonderful art style that certainly stands out
+Funny enough dialogue, with some nice homages to Phoenix Wring (e.g., step ladders)
+Nice character designs
+Interesting jury system, but will have to play further to see how it actually affects gameplay
+Simplified investigations.

-A few times text gets cut off at the bottom of the screen, regardless of resolution
-I'm not sure if it's a design choice, but parts of the court-room battles are completely devoid of music which deflates a lot of the pacing. A bug?
-The character animations are barely anything, and it's bare for even Ace Attorney standards of minimalism--would have liked to see more effort into some animations to spice up what ammounts to a text-heavy game.

The twist at the end of the first case is a strange move, in my opinion, but reserve judgment on it to see if it affects the whole game. If not, I don't like it very much. There's a lot to like with this game, but I think some bugs at launch will hurt it. While there are a lot of details in some aspects, I think there are some woefully plain aspects as well.

I would recommend this game with some reservations, giving it a 6/10 thus far because of some bugs/design choices. In the absence of the above mentioned bugs, I would give this game, post-1st case, a 7/10.

Simple fun, but appealing to only a very niche crowd.

19857606.review:
Witty, well-written, and managing to throw in some twists and turns, I would definitely recommend Aviary Attorney to anyone looking for a narrative-driven game!
It plays very similarly to the Ace Attorney games, you start by being given a case by a (possibly) falsely accused individual. After this, you explore locales related to the crime, collecting evidence and testimony. Once that's done, you go to the courtroom and try to outwit the prosecutor by cross-examining witness testimonies with evidence.
What sets this apart from the Ace Attorney series has to be the way that decisions make the game play out. A poorly worded sentence or illegally acquired evidence can bar you from a useful piece of information for the trial. Does this change the course of the trial? I'm not entirely sure, even after the first case, I want to go in for another go to get those pieces of evidence I couldn't get before.
The game gives off a great atmosphere. The art is superb and very reminiscent of Victorian-style ink drawings. Character portraits will move around the screen in conjunction with actual movement, which on paper sounds small, but in a visual novel-style game it helps to immerse you in what the characters are doing.
The writing is superb. There are some laugh-out-loud funny moments in here, which is an achievement in itself.
To be honest, I bought this game on a whim, being a bit of an avian fanatic. But I was not disappointed in what I got from this, and I have yet to play the full game, even.

EDIT:
I guess if there were one thing to comment on right now, the game doesn't seem to be 100% finished at this time. I was playing through part three and got to a certain point, and I'm guessing it's just the path that I was sent through based on my actions, but after I hit a certain point I was given a screen telling me to check back in a couple of days after an update or to go back and try to go for a different ending. Hopefully it gets up soon, I was really curious as to how my ending would go.

19855724.review:
As a fan of birds and of the Phoenix Wright (Ace Attorney) games I was already sold, but I am pleased to see that gameplay-wise it is not in fact a mere copy of Phoenix Wright giving you significantly more (real) choices that lead to very different outcomes. Here, no matter how well or badly you do your job life goes on. Given the nonlinear nature of this game and the branching paths one can take as a player makes this a game that can be replayed several times. 

The art and music are beautiful and a great testament to how there are all kinds of materials out there for us to tell stories with and that the use we make of those ressources can give them new value and meaning. 

On the downside there are still some unresolved bugs and some of the text seems to contain typos ( ? ) but I am confident these issues will be fixed soon.

If you (like me) like birds and the Ace Attorney franchise or point and click adventure games in general you are sure to enjoy this.

EDIT: I forgot to mention that I have not laughed so much with a game in a while!

19851253.review:
Disclaimer: The review key for this product was provided by the developer free of charge. 
Check out this review and others at Nouse Gaming: http://www.nouse.co.uk/muse/gaming/
------------------------------------------------
It is 1848, Paris. Even in the city of lights darkness still festers. But there are those who stand against the rising tide of evil. Foremost amongst these bastions of hope is one man. Well okay maybe he isn't really up there in the scheme of things. And maybe he isn't technically a man, he's a falcon. But nonetheless he stands to see justice prevails in the heart of revolution.

Aviary Attorney is one of those games looks interesting but maybe you don't expect that much from.  However I'm very pleased to say that it's maybe one of the biggest surprise delights I've had all year.  The game play for Aviary Attorney falls somewhere in between Hatoful Boyfriend and Phoenix Wright. You must traipse through the streets of Paris searching for clues and evidence in order to prevail at court and let the truth out.

However you mustn't let the rather simple outward appearance of the game's mechanics take your guard down. What seems like a straight forward search for the key piece of evidence and then compare it to the correct bit of testimony at court at first quickly reveals itself to be a much more complex and far darker plot. For perhaps obvious reasons I shan't go into any detail but suffice to say that there are more twists and turns in this plot than a particularly rotated piece of Fussili.

Your own personal detective skills are tested as you must choose which leads to follow and which to drop, if pushing a potential witness will give you that vital information or push them away and choosing which location will give you valuable evidence. The game has you on a ticking clock meaning that the decisions that you make have real weight and it has no qualms about letting you miss vital bits of evidence that may prove your downfall in court. You are also limited in funds, some task will require that you acquire items or 'persuade' somebody a few franks changing wings can make this all the easier. More than once you know that there is some kind of connection but with only a limited amount of time and resources you simply cannot secure the evidence you require.

Aviary Attorney smashed my expectations. The writing is superbly witty and hilarious without relying on bird puns (though there are still of few of those for good measure) with gameplay that is far more complex than it might at first appear. The soundtracks pretty good too. The story is a great foray into trying to uphold justice against whatever force may try to stop you. Even the populous that you try to protect. After all, this is Paris. A revolution is never far away.

19837119.review:
Aviary Attorney is a game made in the style of Ace Attorney, featuring woodcut art, a pleasant, classical soundtrack, and colorful animal characters.

Its beautiful woodcut art-style lends characters an immediate visual flair and POP. Coupled with the solid writing and at least one or two interesting twists thus far - I've finished the first act - I can happily say it is at least equal with the more famous Lawyer Game's writing. 

Much like Ace Attorney, you follow an Attorney - here, one JJ Falcon - and his Assistant - Sparrowson -. The two have a delightful dynamic, and descriptions for items and the locations you find are, while punny, quite delightful. 

If you've ever played an Ace Attorney game, you should know what to expect; you go to locations, examine specific items - which are highlighted for you, to prevent tedious pixelhunting - and, later on, use those items and your findings in trials, to prove your points and make objections.

It's not wholly identical to Ace Attorney, however. Going to certain locations takes up a day's time, and it is possible to lose favor with the jury by needlessly pressing on witness statements.  These statements have, thus far tended more towards being clear, concise pieces of logic; a vital necessity given the way the game works. 

In short, if you're a fan of the Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney series, you owe it to yourself to pick up Aviary Attorney.

19836572.review:
Birds have a long history in gaming, dating back to the mascot wars of the 90s. Games like Sonic the Hedgehog, Spyro the Dragon, and Crash Bandicoot all brought birds to the forefront of gaming entertainment with their colorful bird protagonists, hinting at a bright future for avian kind. But as console generations came and went, the medium's focus shifted, and birds were all but lost in the gaming spectrum. Thankfully, all is not lost, and thanks to sleeper hits like Hatoful Boyfriend and Penguins Arena and the popular Tropes vs. Birds video series by Tweeta Parakeetian, birds are back, and better than ever - which brings us to the latest in bird entertainment, Aviary Attorney.

Avian Attorney is, as it says in the title, a game about birds practicing in the school of law - unlike its bird of a feather, Hatoful Boyfriend (which held its surprise so close to its plumage that even today most people still think it's a joke game about dating birds), this time it's just you, the birds, and the mysteries within. While it's not necessarily an original idea, predated by famous bird lawyer series Harvey Birdman: Attorney at Law more than a decade ago, it provides a fresh perspective through its unique presentation, in both its art style and music.

In terms of gameplay, Aviary Attorney will probably come as second nature to anyone familiar with the similarly named Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney series (which, despite its misleading title, is not about mystical birds). It's a visual novel with mystery elements, in which you travel between various locations gathering evidence leading up to a court trial. Unlike Phoenix Wright, however, travelling between most locations takes a day of your time, and you only have a certain amount of time before each court session begins, making you think more about where you need to go. There are four cases, with minor choices throughout the cases that lend to replayability (and frequently leave you wondering whether or not you've made a mistake), and the fourth case has 3 varients which are vary significantly both in story and length, and altogether the game lasted me around 7 hours. There are occasional bugs here and there, but the developer seems to be working hard to iron out the problems and in the time I've been playing it there have already been two small patches for it. If you're a fan of mystery games, particularly of the Ace Attorney variety, this is a pretty easy purchase overall. It has enough original elements to keep veterans of the genre on their talons, while providing more of the mysteries that they love.

Poorly polished game that turned out to be less interesting and challenging than I'd hoped. 

First, there was a serious bug in the game when I played that caused me to lose the entire first chapter. After searching online, I found that some others had come across this bug (see: https://steamcommunity.com/app/384630/discussions/0/458607518210645753/) and that there was no fix besides maybe restarting the entire game and seeing if might be different the second time! 

After finally just accepting that loss and trying to move on (despite being constantly reminded by other characters that I'd lost a case that I never should have lost in the first place!), I found the game itself to be kind of ridiculous and flimsy plot-wise. The investigative phase is mostly just clicking a bunch of things and having the game figure out all the important stuff for you. The trials themselves made little sense logically and weren't all that engaging either. The thing that really bothered me was that you, as the defense attorney, were able to bring in evidence you found on your own at the crime scene, and absolutely no one would question the authenticity or admissability of this evidence! The absurdity of this was just too much for me. I also found the jury pretty mindless. They'd be swayed by trivial things or things that hadn't even been explained yet. 

I do have to admit that the art style, the music, and the humor are done extremely well. But they just can't make up for the other, more prominent inadequacies.

Внезапно, лютая годнота (хотя цена завышенная, конечно).
Я долго сомневался, стоит ли брать игру, потому что синопсис про птицу-адвоката в сеттинге французской монархии откровенно бредовый.
Но здесь бредовость сочетается с остроумными диалогами, сквозными проработанными персонажами и общей нехалтурностью проекта. Конечно, это черно-белая внка с минимумом анимации и тремя часами геймплея, но все эти три часа доставляют равномерное удовольствие, хочется испробовать все реплики и посетить всех персонажей. В копилку плюсом также идет реплайабилити - можно заваливать дела и пропускать улики - игра все равно продолжится, а решения аукнутся позже.
Да, сам геймплей можно назвать традиционным для жанра - сначала ищем улики, потом предьявляем их в суде по мере возникающих вопросов. Но игр-то не так уж и много, Ace Attorney остался на портативках, Данганронпа паталогически анимешна, Детектив Гримуар слишком мультяшен, ну и до кучи можно вспомнить Law & Order: Legacies, снятую с продажи. Если подумать, то Aviary Attorney вполне вписывается в компанию.
В общем, берите, особено по скидке, и два-три вечера в компании двух болтливых пташек пролетят незаметно.

39086251.review:
After playing through just the first case, I was satisfied, impressed, and wanting more - and then I discover there are [i]four cases... with [b]three[/b] endings![/i]  :D  The intricacies and entertainment value of this game made it absolutely amazing and worth the money.
The choices were really hard to make at times, making you think about ethics and justice. There is a lot of replay value here, as you can imagine. The dialogue is fantastic and filled with oh so many puns, some horribly cheesy (like a crocodile named after the sandwich Croc-Monsieur) and some just a subtle play on words or history (e.g. twin wolves Romulus and Remus as a call back to Roman mythology).

I look forward to any future projects by Sketchy Logic <3

39051231.review: Fun and charming game about anthropomorphic animal lawyers in a pre-revolutionary France.  It plays like a choose your own adventure with some point and click elements.  Reminds me of a French Sherlock and Watson if it was in the Wind in the Willows.Funny, witty, charming.

39005142.review:
Un juego de investigación (tipo Ace Attorney) completamente dibujado a mano, protagonizado por pájaros antropomorfos en una trama ambientada en la Francia del siglo XIX. Si nada de lo anterior despierta tu curiosidad, no sé qué lo hará.

Este juego es mejor de lo que tiene derecho a ser. Cualquiera de sus ingredientes, de forma aislada, puede resultar atractivo para algún jugador; y la mezcla de todos ellos resulta novedosa, sin importar el motivo que te atrajo a él.

Con todas estas premisas no esperaba que la trama valiera para nada, pero supera mis expectativas (sin ser tampoco la repera). Tiene diferentes finales dependiendo de lo que hagas en el tercer capítulo. Ninguno te cambiará la vida, pero si te está gustando el juego merece la pena exporarlos todos.

En ocasiones, la mecánica de los interrogatorios es un poco obtusa: tú sabes las pruebas que has reunido y qué quieres alegar, pero no sabes cómo espera el juego que las presentes. Vas haciendo prueba y error a ver cómo sacas una prueba concreta, y algunas de ellas solo las puedes presentar porque mágicamente llega un personaje en medio del juicio y por fin puedes mencionar la prueba que querías mencionar. No sé en los Ace Attorney pasa lo mismo.

Si no controlas bien el inglés no le vas a sacar tanto jugo como podrías, ni a la trama ni al humor. Puede que hasta te cueste jugarlo. El lenguaje del siglo XIX no lo hace más fácil. Este factor por desgracia va a dejar fuera a gran cantidad de jugadores.

[b]Lo mejor[/b]:
[list] 
[*] Pájaros abogados, colega... Yo leí "pájaros abogados" y ya no necesité leer más.
[*] Mucho sentido del humor.
[*] El arte es definitivamente diferente a lo que estás acostumbrado.
[*] ¡Pájaro abogados!
[/list]

[b]Lo peor[/b]:
[list]
[*] Inglés bastante avanzado, y mucha lectura.
[*] No siempre está claro cómo argumentar el caso.
[/list]

38993818.review:
This is a short game, clocking in at just under 4 hours for me, but I still found Aviary Attorney an interesting, jaunty ride with good use of art, music, and writing to keep my attention through to the end. I think a failure in any three of those areas would have rendered this a subpar experience, but everything came together in the end. This isn't to say that it is some masterwork of the genre by any means, but I found it satisfying as a brief escape from reality that was easy to digest in bite-size one hour chunks.

I would have preferred for the game to have had at least another two acts to allow more emersion into the setting and characters, but I am satisfied with the amount of value I got out of this game buying it on sale.
